conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If corruption is never punished and doesn't affect tenure (Z), then the lack of convictions accurately reflects high ethical standards.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to SURVIVORSHIP. We cannot determine whether longevity proves ethics without knowing if corrupt politicians are filtered out early (Z). If they are removed before reaching 20 years, then the sample is biased and the claim is false. If tenure is independent of ethics, the claim is justified. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: Selection on the dependent variable. We are looking for corruption in a group defined by *not* having been removed for corruption.
hidden_timestamp: Do corrupt politicians get voted out or arrested before reaching 20 years?

scenario: A study of successful 'Unicorn' fintech startups (X) that survived regulatory vetting (Z) reveals they all used a specific legal loophole (Y). A VC advises new startups to use this loophole to guarantee success.
claim: Using the loophole causes success.
label: NO
causal_structure: Many startups used the loophole (Y). Some were shut down by regulators (Z) and died. Only the lucky survivors (X) are observed.
key_insight: We don't see the startups that used the loophole and were fined into bankruptcy.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If many failed startups also used the loophole but were shut down (Z), the strategy is high-risk and the claim of guaranteed success is false.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If no failed startups ever used the loophole (Z), then it may be a genuine differentiator for success.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to SURVIVORSHIP. We cannot determine if the loophole causes success without knowing how many startups used it and failed (Z). If failures also used the loophole and were shut down, the claim is false. If only successful ones used it, the claim is justified. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: Standard business survivorship bias. Analyzing traits of winners without comparing to losers who had the same traits.
hidden_timestamp: How many failed startups also used the loophole?

scenario: A police K9 unit reports that in 95% of cases where a dog alerted and a search was conducted (X/Z), drugs were found (Y). The department claims the dogs are 95% accurate.
claim: Drug dogs are 95% accurate.
label: NO
causal_structure: We only observe accuracy when a search happens. We never observe times the dog *failed* to alert when drugs were present (Z).
key_insight: Accuracy requires knowing False Positives AND False Negatives. We only see True Positives and False Positives.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the dog frequently fails to alert when drugs are present (Z=0), its overall accuracy is much lower than 95%, making the claim false.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the dog never misses drugs (zero false negatives) even when it doesn't alert (Z=0), then the 95% precision matches the total accuracy.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to SURVIVORSHIP. We cannot determine total accuracy without knowing how often the dog fails to alert when drugs are present (Z). If the dog has many false negatives, the claim is false. If the dog never misses drugs, the claim is justified. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: Observational censoring. The 'negative' cases (no alert) are never verified, so 'misses' are invisible.
hidden_timestamp: How often were drugs present but the dog did not alert?

scenario: A study of whistleblowers (Z) finds that those who reported financial fraud (X) were far less likely to have personal grievances (Y) against their employer than those who reported safety violations. A journalist concludes financial fraud is so objective it compels even happy employees to report it.
claim: Financial fraud reporting is driven by objectivity, not grievances.
label: NO
causal_structure: Whistleblowing (Z) requires Major Issue (X) OR Personal Vendetta (Y).
key_insight: People blow the whistle because the crime is huge or because they hate the boss.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If whistleblowing requires a threshold of motivation (severity + anger), the correlation is spurious.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If whistleblowing is random, the conclusion holds.

wise_refusal: The claim that financial fraud reporting is driven by objectivity is ambiguous due to a COLLIDER trap. We cannot determine whether reporting is driven by objectivity or if the pattern is a statistical artifact without knowing whether the decision to blow the whistle (Z) depends on both the type of fraud (X) and personal grievances (Y). If whistleblowing requires a threshold of motivation met by either factor, then the correlation is spurious due to selection bias. If whistleblowing occurs randomly, then the causal claim may be justified. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: Conditioning on the common effect Z (Whistleblowing). If Z = X OR Y, then X and Y will be negatively correlated in the sample of whistleblowers even if they are independent in the general population.
hidden_timestamp: Does the decision to blow the whistle depend on the severity of the issue and personal grievances?

scenario: In a long-term study of a new cancer drug, patients who completed the full 12-month treatment course (X) survived significantly longer (Y) than those assigned to the control group. This analysis potentially excludes patients who suffered an early death (Z) before the 12-month mark. The pharma company claims the drug extends life.
claim: The drug extends patient survival.
label: NO
causal_structure: Completing treatment requires surviving 12 months; control group deaths count from Day 1.
key_insight: Patients who died in month 3 are excluded from 'Completed Treatment' but included in Control.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the analysis uses 'Intent-to-Treat' (including all patients who started), the claim is valid.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the analysis only counts 'Completers', it introduces immortal time bias because the 'completer' group is guaranteed to have survived 12 months.

wise_refusal: The claim that the drug extends patient survival is ambiguous due to IMMORTAL TIME. We cannot determine whether the drug is effective or the result is biased without knowing if patients who suffered an early death (Z) were excluded from the treatment analysis. If the study used an intent-to-treat analysis, then the claim is justified. If the study only included 'completers' who finished the 12-month course (X), then the results are biased by immortal time. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: Immortal time bias: To be classified as having "completed treatment" (X), a patient must survive (Y) the entire 12-month course. This excludes early deaths (Z) from the treatment group while including them in the control group, creating an artificial survival advantage for "completers".
hidden_timestamp: Did the analysis exclude treated patients who died before month 12?

scenario: A study of law firms found that firms in business for over 50 years (X) have never filed for bankruptcy (Y). This study only samples current firms and does not account for firm survival (Z) among companies that started at the same time. A consultant advises new firms to adopt the 'conservative billing practices' of these old firms to avoid bankruptcy.
claim: Conservative billing prevents bankruptcy.
label: NO
causal_structure: Firms that went bankrupt didn't make it to 50 years to be in the sample.
key_insight: You have to avoid bankruptcy to be 50 years old.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If we track a full cohort from their founding and see that billing practices predict lower bankruptcy rates, the claim is supported.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If we only look at current old firms, the lack of bankruptcy is a tautology of their survival, not proof of the efficacy of billing practices.

wise_refusal: The claim that conservative billing prevents bankruptcy is ambiguous due to IMMORTAL TIME bias. We cannot determine whether the practices are effective or if the results are due to survivorship without knowing if the study tracked the full cohort of starting firms to account for firm survival (Z). If the study tracked all firms from inception, the claim may be valid. If the study only looked at current survivors, the result is biased. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: Survivorship bias/Immortal time: Firms that went bankrupt (Y) are excluded from the sample of "firms in business for >50 years" (X) by definition. The lack of bankruptcy among survivors is a tautology of their longevity, not evidence that their specific practices prevent failure.
hidden_timestamp: Are we looking at the full cohort of firms started 50 years ago?

scenario: A gig economy platform reports that 'Power Users' (drivers active for >2 years) (X) earn 20% more per hour (Y) than the average driver. However, the data does not specify the rate of driver attrition (Z) among those who earn less. They claim their platform rewards loyalty with better algorithms.
claim: The platform's algorithms reward loyalty with higher pay.
label: NO
causal_structure: Drivers who earn low wages quit before reaching 2 years.
key_insight: Survival in the system is conditional on the outcome (wages).

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If individual driver wages actually increased over time, the claim that algorithms reward loyalty is supported.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If wages are static and the difference is due to low-earners quitting (Z), then the result is an artifact of attrition bias.

wise_refusal: The claim that the platform's algorithms reward loyalty is ambiguous due to IMMORTAL TIME bias. We cannot determine whether algorithms increase pay or if low-earners simply quit without knowing the rate of driver attrition (Z). If wages for individual drivers rose over two years, then the claim is justified. If the difference is driven by low-earning drivers quitting before two years, then the claim is not supported. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: Attrition bias/Immortal time: To reach "Power User" status (X), a driver must survive two years on the platform. Drivers who earn low wages (Y) are more likely to quit early, meaning the long-term group is naturally selected for higher earners, regardless of any loyalty rewards.
hidden_timestamp: Did wages rise over time, or did low-wage drivers quit early?

scenario: A city implemented a 'Night Owl' bus service (X). Data shows that riders who used the service regularly for a year (X) were never arrested for DUI (Y). However, the study does not mention if riders who were arrested and faced incarceration (Z) were excluded from the 'regular user' count. The Mayor claims the bus prevents 100% of DUIs for its users.
claim: The Night Owl bus prevents DUIs.
label: NO
causal_structure: If you get a DUI, you might lose your job/freedom and stop taking the bus regularily.
key_insight: You have to stay out of jail to be a 'regular user' for a year.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the study tracks all initial users regardless of whether they finished the year, the claim is supported.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the definition of 'regular user' requires a full year of active use, it inherently excludes anyone whose usage was stopped by a DUI arrest (Z).

wise_refusal: The claim that the Night Owl bus prevents DUIs is ambiguous due to IMMORTAL TIME bias. We cannot determine whether the bus reduces DUIs or if the sample is biased without knowing if riders who faced incarceration (Z) were excluded from the treatment group. If the study tracked all initial riders, then the claim is justified. If only those who used the service for a full year (X) were counted, then the result is biased. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: Immortal time/Reverse Survival: Defining the group as "regular users for a full year" (X) excludes anyone whose bus usage was interrupted by a DUI arrest (Y) and subsequent incarceration or job loss. The treatment group is thus defined by the successful avoidance of the outcome.
hidden_timestamp: Does 'regular user' exclude people who used it for 6 months and then got arrested?

scenario: In 2024, the Mayor's office identified the police precinct with the highest rate of civilian complaints in the city (Precinct 9), which was an extreme outlier (Z). Citing a 'crisis of leadership', they replaced the precinct commander (X). In 2025, civilian complaints in Precinct 9 dropped by 30% (Y) to match the citywide average.
claim: The new commander's leadership successfully reduced complaints.
label: NO
causal_structure: Precinct 9 was selected because of an extreme value (Z). Extreme values naturally tend to regress to the mean in subsequent measurements, regardless of the intervention (X).
key_insight: When an intervention is triggered by a 'record high', a subsequent drop is statistically expected even if the intervention is useless.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If 2024 was a statistical outlier for Precinct 9, the drop (Y) is likely regression to the mean (Z).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If Precinct 9 had a consistent history of high complaints, the drop (Y) is more likely due to the new commander (X).

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to REGRESSION. We cannot determine whether the drop (Y) was due to the new commander (X) or Regression to the Mean (Z) without knowing if 2024 was an anomaly. If 2024 was an outlier year, the drop is likely a statistical artifact. If the precinct had consistently high complaints for years, then the commander's leadership likely caused the improvement. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: The intervention was applied to an outlier (highest rate). Outliers typically regress toward the mean in subsequent periods. The improvement is likely a statistical artifact.
hidden_timestamp: Did the precinct have a history of high complaints, or was 2024 a statistical outlier?

scenario: A public health initiative utilized 2023 hospital data to identify the 'Top 50' citizens with the highest number of emergency room visits (Z). These individuals were assigned a 'Community Health Liaison' (X). In 2024, the total ER visits for this specific group dropped by 50% (Y).
claim: The Liaison program successfully reduced ER usage.
label: NO
causal_structure: Patients selected at their peak usage (Z) will naturally have fewer visits (Y) as their crises resolve, regardless of the Liaison (X).
key_insight: Medical 'super-users' often have temporary spikes in usage that resolve naturally.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the high usage in 2023 was due to acute, transient events, the drop (Y) is Regression to the Mean (Z).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the patients had chronically high usage for many years, the drop (Y) suggests the Liaison program (X) was effective.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to REGRESSION. We cannot determine whether the drop (Y) was due to the Liaison program (X) or Regression to the Mean (Z) without knowing if the high usage was chronic. If the 2023 visits were a temporary spike, the decline is natural. If the usage was consistently high for years, the program likely worked. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: Selection was based on an extreme value (Top 50 visits). High medical usage is often episodic. The decline is expected as patients recover from the acute events that put them on the list.
hidden_timestamp: Did the high ER usage persist for multiple years prior to 2023?

scenario: Juries in the state's wealthiest judicial districts (X) award significantly higher damages in civil suits (Y) than juries in lower-income districts. These districts have vastly different Local Costs of Living (Z), which impacts damage calculations. A lawyer argues that wealthy people are inherently more generous jurors.
claim: Wealthy jurors are more generous.
label: NO
causal_structure: Wealthy districts (Z) have higher costs of living and earnings, meaning lost-wage and medical claims (Y) are mathematically larger.
key_insight: Damages often scale with the economic environment, not juror psychology.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If jurors in wealthy districts award the same amount for identical cases as those in poor districts once Local Costs (Z) are adjusted, the difference is an ecological artifact.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If jurors in wealthy districts award more for identical cases, juror generosity may be a factor.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to the ECOLOGICAL trap. We cannot determine if wealthy individuals are more generous without knowing if they award more for the same case across districts with different Costs of Living (Z). If awards are identical for the same case, the district-level difference is an artifact. If awards differ, the claim is justified. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: Aggregate awards track with the economic value of the claims (Z), which is higher in wealthy areas. This is a compositional effect of the cases, not necessarily a trait of the individuals.
hidden_timestamp: Does the pattern of higher awards (Y) hold when comparing identical cases across districts (Z)?

scenario: A period of global input cost inflation (Z) caused smaller firms to exit the market, leading to high market concentration (X). During this same period, prices (Y) in these industries increased by 15%.
claim: Market concentration caused the price increases.
label: NO
causal_structure: Input costs (Z) drive both market concentration (X) and price hikes (Y), making the X-Y relationship potentially spurious.
key_insight: Did prices rise in competitive industries too?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If competitive industries facing the same cost shocks also raised prices by 15%, the cause is input costs (Z).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If only concentrated industries raised prices significantly, concentration (X) is the likely cause.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to a CONFOUNDER. We cannot determine whether concentration (X) or input costs (Z) caused the price hike without knowing if prices rose similarly in unconcentrated industries. If they did, then the inflation (Z) is the cause. If only concentrated industries saw the hike, then market concentration (X) is the cause. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: Global cost shocks (Z) are a common cause for both market structure changes (X) and price hikes (Y).
hidden_timestamp: Did prices rise in unconcentrated industries with similar cost structures?

scenario: Border patrol identified specific sectors as high-traffic routes (Z). In response, the government built a new wall (X) in those sectors. Shortly after construction, those sectors saw an increase in apprehensions (Y).
claim: Building the wall causes more illegal crossings.
label: NO
causal_structure: High traffic (Z) leads to both the decision to build a wall (X) and the high apprehension numbers (Y).
key_insight: Walls are built where people are already crossing.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the high traffic (Z) preceded the wall and remained the same, then Z is the common cause of X and Y.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If traffic was low before construction and spiked only after, then the wall (X) might be a causal factor.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to a CONFOUNDER. We cannot determine whether the wall (X) or the pre-existing traffic (Z) caused the high apprehensions without knowing the traffic levels before construction. If the sector was already high-traffic, then Z is the cause. If traffic rose only after building, then X might be the cause. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: High traffic (Z) causes the location of the wall (X) and the volume of apprehensions (Y).
hidden_timestamp: Was the sector a high-traffic route (Z) before the wall was built?

scenario: Companies with high crisis management competence (Z) typically disclose data breaches within 24 hours (X) and also maintain lower long-term stock drops (Y) compared to companies with poor management.
claim: Immediate disclosure protects stock value.
label: NO
causal_structure: Competent management (Z) ensures both rapid disclosure (X) and effective recovery (Y).
key_insight: Rapid disclosure is a signal of competence, not necessarily the cause of stability.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If incompetent companies that disclose early still suffer massive crashes, then competence (Z) is the true cause.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If disclosure itself builds market trust regardless of underlying competence, then X causes Y.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to a CONFOUNDER. We cannot determine whether immediate disclosure (X) or crisis management competence (Z) protects the stock without knowing the outcome for incompetent firms that disclose quickly. If they still crash, then competence (Z) is the cause. If they remain stable, then disclosure (X) is the cause. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: Competence (Z) drives both the ability to disclose quickly (X) and the ability to reassure markets (Y).
hidden_timestamp: Does the company have a robust crisis plan (Z)?

scenario: During house fires (Z), homes where a fire extinguisher (X) was used suffer more fire damage (Y) on average than homes where one was not used.
claim: Fire extinguishers cause more fire damage.
label: NO
causal_structure: The fire (Z) causes both the use of the extinguisher (X) and the damage (Y).
key_insight: Extinguishers are associated with fires because they are used *in* fires.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the fire (Z) is the cause of both the usage and the damage, the association is spurious.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the extinguisher (X) malfunctioned and accelerated the fire, then X could be the cause.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to a CONFOUNDER. We cannot determine whether the extinguisher (X) or the fire (Z) caused the damage without knowing the severity of the fire before usage. If the fire (Z) was already causing damage, then Z is the cause. If damage only occurred after usage, then the extinguisher (X) might be responsible. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: The occurrence of a fire (Z) causes both the damage (Y) and the use/presence of the extinguisher (X) in the damage report.
hidden_timestamp: Did the fire (Z) start before the extinguisher was used?

scenario: Couples who sign prenuptial agreements (X) have a higher divorce rate (Y) than those who do not. These couples often have significant asset disparities or pre-existing trust issues (Z). A marriage counselor advises against prenups to ensure a lasting marriage.
claim: Prenups cause divorce.
label: NO
causal_structure: Lack of trust or realistic expectations (Z) leads to both prenups (X) and divorce (Y).
key_insight: Couples who anticipate divorce (Z) prepare for it.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If trust issues (Z) existed before the signing, then Z causes both the prenup (X) and the divorce (Y).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If no prior trust issues existed but the negotiation of the prenup (X) created new conflict, then X may contribute to the divorce (Y).

wise_refusal: The claim that prenups cause divorce is ambiguous due to confounding. We cannot determine whether the prenup (X) causes the divorce (Y) without knowing if significant trust issues or asset disparities (Z) were present beforehand. If trust issues (Z) existed, they likely caused both the prenup (X) and the divorce (Y). If trust issues were absent but the prenup negotiation (X) created the conflict, then X could cause Y. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: Underlying factors like lack of romantic idealism or asset protection needs (Z) drive both the legal contract (X) and the higher likelihood of separation (Y).
hidden_timestamp: Did trust issues (Z) exist before the prenup was signed?

scenario: Protests occurring in designated 'Free Speech Zones' (X) are more likely to turn violent (Y) than unzoned protests. Police typically only mandate these zones for protests already assessed as having high tension or a high threat level (Z). The police chief concludes zones incite violence.
claim: Free Speech Zones cause violence.
label: NO
causal_structure: Police mandate zones (X) only for protests deemed high-risk (Z). High risk leads to violence (Y).
key_insight: Zones are applied to dangerous protests, not peaceful ones.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the protest was assessed as high-risk (Z), then the risk caused both the zone (X) and the violence (Y).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the protest was not high-risk but the zone (X) itself created tension, then the zone may have caused the violence (Y).

wise_refusal: The claim that Free Speech Zones cause violence is ambiguous due to confounding. We cannot determine whether the zone (X) incites violence (Y) without knowing if the protest was assessed as high-risk (Z) before the zone was mandated. If the protest was high-risk (Z), this risk likely accounts for both the zone (X) and the violence (Y). If the zone (X) itself created tension that led to violence, then X could cause Y. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: The threat assessment (Z) causes both the imposition of the zone (X) and the likelihood of violence (Y).
hidden_timestamp: Was the protest assessed as 'High Risk' (Z) before the zone was mandated?

scenario: Products with 'Choking Hazard' labels (X) are involved in more choking incidents (Y) than products without labels. These labeled products almost always contain small parts (Z). A parent avoids labeled toys, thinking they are safer without the label.
claim: Warning labels cause choking.
label: NO
causal_structure: Small parts (Z) cause the need for a label (X) and the risk of choking (Y).
key_insight: The label warns of the risk (Z); it doesn't create it.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the product contains small parts (Z), then the parts cause both the label (X) and the choking (Y).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the product does not contain small parts (Z) but still has a label, the label (X) itself would need to be the cause of choking (Y), which is unlikely.

wise_refusal: The claim that warning labels cause choking is ambiguous due to confounding. We cannot determine whether the label (X) causes the choking incident (Y) without knowing if the product contains small parts (Z). If the product has small parts (Z), then these parts cause both the label (X) and the choking risk (Y). If the product lacks small parts, then the label (X) could theoretically cause the incident (Y). Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: The physical hazard (Z) causes both the regulation requiring a label (X) and the injury (Y).
hidden_timestamp: Did the product contain small parts (Z) before the label was applied?

scenario: Unionized factories (X) report more injuries per worker (Y) than non-union factories, though unionization is much more common in high-hazard heavy industries (Z). An anti-union lobbyist claims unions protect unsafe workers.
claim: Unions cause workplace injuries.
label: NO
causal_structure: Unions are prevalent in dangerous heavy industries (Z=High Risk) like mining/steel. Non-unions are in light assembly (Z=Low Risk).
key_insight: Dangerous jobs organize; unions don't make jobs dangerous.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If we stratify by Industry (e.g., just Steel), unionized plants likely have fewer injuries.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If we aggregate all sectors, the heavy industry bias makes unions look unsafe.

wise_refusal: The claim that unions cause workplace injuries is ambiguous due to Simpson's Paradox. We cannot determine the causal effect without knowing the stratified injury rates by industry hazard level (Z). If unions are simply concentrated in naturally dangerous industries, then the claim is likely false. If injury rates remain higher even within factories of the same hazard level, then the claim might be justified. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: Industry hazard level (Z) causes both Unionization (X) and Injuries (Y). Aggregating diverse industries confounds the safety record.
hidden_timestamp: Are the factories being compared within the same industry and hazard level?

scenario: A city council reviews dog bite statistics and finds that dogs whose owners purchased heavy-duty muzzles (X) were involved in 300% more biting incidents (Y) over the last year than dogs without muzzles. However, the report did not account for the dogs' prior aggression history (Z). A council member proposes banning muzzles, arguing that they make dogs more aggressive.
claim: Muzzles cause dogs to become aggressive and bite.
label: NO
causal_structure: Owners of dogs with a history of aggression (Z/Y) are the ones who buy muzzles (X). The aggression causes the muzzle purchase, not vice versa.
key_insight: The safety measure is a response to the risk, not the cause of it.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the dogs were docile before the muzzle and aggressive after, the muzzle might be the cause.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the dogs had a history of biting before the muzzle was bought, the correlation is reverse causation.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to Reverse Causation. We cannot determine whether muzzles caused aggression or aggression caused muzzle use without knowing the dogs' prior aggression history (Z). If the dogs were docile before the muzzle (X) and became aggressive after, then the muzzles might be the cause. If the dogs already had a history of aggression (Z) before the purchase (X), then the correlation is due to reverse causation. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: This is a classic reverse causation case. Responsible owners of aggressive dogs buy muzzles to prevent bites. The correlation exists because high-risk dogs are selected into the 'muzzled' group.
hidden_timestamp: Did the dog show aggressive behavior before the muzzle was purchased?

scenario: Insurance data reveals that drivers who own radar detectors (X) receive twice as many speeding tickets (Y) as drivers who do not. The data lacks information on the drivers' habitual speeding (Z) behavior prior to owning the devices. A safety advocate argues that radar detectors embolden drivers to speed and should be illegal.
claim: Radar detectors cause drivers to get more speeding tickets.
label: NO
causal_structure: Drivers who habitually speed (Z) are more likely to buy radar detectors (X) to avoid getting caught, but still get caught more often (Y) due to their behavior.
key_insight: The device is purchased by those who intend to engage in the risky behavior.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If ticket rates increased only after buying the detector, the device might encourage speeding.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the driver had high ticket rates before the purchase, the purchase was a reaction to the risk.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to Reverse Causation. We cannot determine whether radar detectors cause speeding or if frequent speeders are more likely to buy them without knowing the drivers' habitual speeding (Z) records prior to the purchase. If ticket rates (Y) increased only after buying the detector (X), then the device might be the cause. If the driver already had a history of habitual speeding (Z) before the purchase (X), then the purchase was a reaction to the risk. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: Habitual speeders select into the 'radar detector owner' group. The cause of the tickets is the underlying driving habit, which also causes the purchase of the detector.
hidden_timestamp: Did the driver have a history of speeding before buying the detector?

scenario: A business magazine reports that companies hiring 'Crisis Management' consultants (X) are 80% more likely to declare bankruptcy (Y) within 12 months than companies that do not. The analysis did not control for the companies' initial level of financial distress (Z). An analyst concludes that these consultants are incompetent and drain company resources, accelerating their demise.
claim: Hiring crisis consultants increases the risk of bankruptcy.
label: NO
causal_structure: Companies in severe financial distress (Z) hire consultants (X) as a last-ditch effort. The distress causes both the hiring and the subsequent bankruptcy (Y).
key_insight: Interventions are often deployed when the negative outcome is already imminent.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the company was healthy before hiring and failed afterwards, the consultants might be to blame.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the company was already in distress, the hiring was a symptom of the impending failure.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to Reverse Causation. We cannot determine whether hiring consultants (X) increases bankruptcy (Y) risk or if companies facing bankruptcy (Y) are more likely to hire them without knowing their initial financial distress (Z) levels. If healthy companies (Z) hire consultants (X) and then fail, the consultants might be to blame. If the companies were already in severe distress (Z) when hiring (X), then the hiring was a symptom of the impending failure. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: The hiring of consultants is a reaction to pre-existing financial trouble. Comparing them to healthy companies creates a false causal link.
hidden_timestamp: Was the company solvent or insolvent at the time the consultants were hired?

scenario: Police deploy riot gear and armored vehicles (X) to a protest, citing intelligence that the crowd is 'hostile'. Upon seeing the armored vehicles, protesters become agitated and throw water bottles (Y), leading to a rapid escalation (Z). The Police Chief states that the throwing of objects proves the riot gear was necessary.
claim: The aggression of the crowd proves the decision to deploy riot gear was correct.
label: NO
causal_structure: The display of force (X) provokes the aggression (Y), which is then used to justify the force (X).
key_insight: Aggressive policing can create the hostility it anticipates.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the crowd was peaceful until the gear arrived, the deployment caused the aggression (Feedback).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the crowd was already violent before the gear appeared, the deployment was a valid response.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to a Feedback Loop (T11). We cannot determine whether the riot gear (X) was a response to violence or the cause of it (Y). If the aggression started only after the armored vehicles appeared, the police presence provoked the reaction. If violence preceded the deployment, the claim is justified. Without a timeline of the escalation, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: The police presence acts as a provocation, eliciting the exact behavior used to justify the presence.
hidden_timestamp: Is there a reinforcing loop where the police presence (X) provokes crowd agitation (Y) which then appears to justify that presence?

scenario: Unionized Factory U provides workers with a mobile app to anonymously log safety hazards (X). Non-union Factory N requires workers to file paper reports in the supervisor's office (Z). Factory U reports 500% more safety hazards (Y) than Factory N.
claim: Factory U is a more dangerous workplace than Factory N.
label: NO
causal_structure: The easy reporting mechanism (X) leads to a higher count of hazards (Y) compared to the high-friction mechanism at Factory N, regardless of actual safety.
key_insight: lowering the friction to report problems increases the number of reported problems.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If Factory N's hazard reports rise to match Factory U's using the same app, the difference is due to reporting bias.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If Factory N's hazard reports remain low after implementing the app, the difference reflects true danger.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to Measurement Bias (Reporting Bias). We cannot determine whether Factory U is actually more dangerous or if the difference is due to the reporting barrier (Z) without knowing if hazard counts would equalize under the same reporting system. If standardized reporting shows similar levels, then the difference is a measurement artifact. If a large gap remains, then Factory U likely has more hazards. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: The method of data collection (X) differs fundamentally. Anonymous digital logging captures minor issues that are filtered out by a non-anonymous paper process.
hidden_timestamp: If Factory N used the same anonymous app, would their reported hazard count match Factory U?

scenario: State A expands its legal definition of 'Domestic Violence' to include verbal harassment and coercive control (X). State B restricts its definition to physical assault only (Z). Statistics show State A has a Domestic Violence rate (Y) three times higher than State B.
claim: State A has a more violent culture than State B.
label: NO
causal_structure: The broader definition (X) captures more behaviors as 'Violence' (Y), inflating the rate relative to State B.
key_insight: You cannot compare rates if the numerator is defined differently.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If State B's rate matches State A's when using the same definition, the difference is purely nominal.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If State B's rate remains lower even under the expanded definition, there may be a cultural difference.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to Measurement Bias (Definitional Artifact). We cannot determine whether State A has a more violent culture or if the difference is due to the classification criteria (Z) without knowing the rates under a standardized definition. If rates equalize under a common definition, then the difference is purely definitional. If a gap remains, then State A may indeed have a more violent culture. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: State A is measuring a broader set of behaviors. Comparing the aggregate rates implies a difference in the underlying phenomenon (violence) which may not exist.
hidden_timestamp: If State B used State A's expanded definition, would their domestic violence rate match State A's?

scenario: Federal law mandates that Publicly Traded Companies report all cyber breaches within 72 hours (X). Private companies have no federal reporting mandate, allowing many hidden private hacks (Z) to go undisclosed. Cybersecurity reports show that 95% of major hacks target Public Companies (Y).
claim: Hackers specifically target Public Companies over Private ones.
label: NO
causal_structure: The legal mandate (X) ensures breaches at Public companies are counted (Y), while breaches at Private companies remain secret.
key_insight: You cannot analyze the distribution of targets if half the potential targets are invisible.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If insurer data shows private companies are hacked at similar rates, the public 'target' preference is an illusion.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If private companies truly have few insurance claims for hacks, the public preference is real.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to Measurement Bias (Reporting Bias). We cannot determine whether hackers target public companies over private ones without knowing the true rate of hidden private hacks (Z). If private companies are hacked at similar rates but do not report them, the observed preference is an illusion. If private companies truly experience very few hacks, then the preference is real. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: The exposure (Public Status) causes the measurement (Reporting), creating a false correlation between Public Status and 'Being Hacked' in the observed data.
hidden_timestamp: What is the rate of hacks among private companies (e.g. from anonymous insurer data)?

scenario: Drivers involved in multi-car pileups (Y) often feel a subconscious need to assign blame (Z) to explain the traumatic event. Interviews show that 95% of these drivers recalled seeing the car that initiated the crash 'weaving erratically' (X) prior to the accident. Investigators are evaluating whether erratic driving was the cause.
claim: Erratic driving caused the pileup.
label: NO
causal_structure: Outcome (Y) creates a need for explanation, generating false memory (X).
key_insight: Witnesses subconsciously invent a 'cause' to explain a chaotic event.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If independent video footage shows the car driving straight, then the reports of weaving (X) were a result of recall bias (Effort after meaning) triggered by the crash (Y).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If independent video footage confirms the weaving, then the witness reports are accurate and the claim is justified.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to RECALL bias (Effort after meaning). We cannot determine whether erratic driving caused the pileup without knowing if the witness accounts (X) are accurate. If objective video confirms the weaving, then the claim is justified. If the video shows the car driving straight, then the witnesses are likely constructing a cause (X) to explain the trauma (Y) and assign blame (Z). Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: The severity of the outcome (Y) drives the brain to manufacture a plausible cause (X). Objective evidence is needed to distinguish truth from bias.
hidden_timestamp: Do the witness accounts of erratic driving (X) match the objective reality, or are they biased by the outcome (Y)?

scenario: A tenant advocacy group reports that tenants who were evicted (Y) and harbor significant grievance (Z) recall their landlords 'refusing maintenance requests' (X) twice as often as tenants who moved out voluntarily. The group argues this demonstrates a pattern of landlord neglect.
claim: Landlords neglect the apartments of tenants they intend to evict.
label: NO
causal_structure: Eviction (Y) biases memory of landlord interactions (X).
key_insight: The adversarial nature of eviction colors the memory of the relationship.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If objective maintenance logs show equal response rates for all tenants, then the reports of neglect (X) were likely a product of recall bias caused by the eviction (Y).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If objective maintenance logs confirm that requests from evicted tenants were ignored, then the claim of neglect is justified.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to RECALL bias (rumination bias). We cannot determine whether landlords neglect apartments without knowing if the tenants' recall (X) matches objective facts. If maintenance logs show the requests were ignored, the claim is justified. If logs show standard response rates, then the tenants' recall is likely biased by the grievance (Z) of eviction (Y). Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: The negative outcome (Y) creates a lens through which past events (X) are viewed. Objective data is required to resolve the ambiguity.
hidden_timestamp: Is the reported neglect (X) an accurate recall of landlord behavior, or is it biased by the grievance (Z) of eviction (Y)?

scenario: Parents of students who failed the year (Y) often exhibit defensive attribution (Z) to protect their child's self-esteem. These parents recall the teacher 'ignoring their child's raised hand' (X) significantly more often than parents of passing students. The parents' association claims this shows discriminatory behavior.
claim: The teacher discriminates against struggling students.
label: NO
causal_structure: Failure (Y) leads to externalizing blame via biased memory (X).
key_insight: Negative outcomes motivate observers to find an external cause that protects self-esteem.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If classroom video recordings show the teacher called on all students at equal rates, then the parents' recall (X) was a product of bias triggered by the student's failure (Y).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If classroom video recordings confirm the teacher ignored the students who failed, then the claim of discrimination is justified.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to RECALL bias (Effort after meaning). We cannot determine whether the teacher discriminated without knowing if the parents' recall (X) is accurate. If objective video evidence shows the teacher ignoring the students, the claim is justified. If the video shows equal attention, then the parents are likely externalizing the failure (Y) via biased memory (X) to protect self-esteem (Z). Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: The outcome (failure) motivates the observer to find a cause that protects self-esteem. Objective evidence is needed to resolve the potential recall bias.
hidden_timestamp: Is the parents' recall of the teacher ignoring students (X) accurate, or is it a result of defensive attribution (Z) following the failure (Y)?

scenario: Investors who lost money in the 'Omega' IPO (Y) frequently perform an outcome-dependent evaluation (Z) of the offering documents. These investors claim the prospectus was 'confusing and deceptive' (X), whereas those who profited found it clear. Regulators are debating whether the document was deceptively written.
claim: The prospectus was deceptively written.
label: NO
causal_structure: Financial loss (Y) biases the interpretation of the document (X).
key_insight: The document didn't change; the investors' outcome changed their perception of it.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If an objective linguistic analysis shows the prospectus complexity was standard for the industry, then the perception of deception (X) was a product of recall bias caused by the loss (Y).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If an objective linguistic analysis shows the text was unusually convoluted or ambiguous, then the claim of deception is justified.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to RECALL bias (Effort after meaning). We cannot determine whether the prospectus was deceptive without an objective benchmark. If a linguistic analysis shows the text was unusually convoluted, the claim is justified. If the analysis shows the text was standard, then the perception of deception (X) is likely a result of the retrospective evaluation (Z) following the financial loss (Y). Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: The outcome (Y) drives the subjective evaluation (X). Objective metrics are needed to determine if the document was fundamentally deceptive.
hidden_timestamp: Is the perception of the prospectus as deceptive (X) based on objective textual ambiguity, or is it a result of outcome-dependent bias (Z) caused by the financial loss (Y)?

scenario: A company aims to reduce 'Reputational Risk' from lawsuits (X). They implement a mandatory arbitration clause and strict Non-Disclosure Agreements (NDAs) for all employees (Z). The number of public discrimination lawsuits filed against the firm drops to zero (Y).
claim: The company has eliminated workplace discrimination.
label: NO
causal_structure: The goal of avoiding public lawsuits (X) led to legal suppression (Z), hiding the discrimination rather than stopping it (Y).
key_insight: Absence of evidence (lawsuits) is not evidence of absence when the evidence is actively suppressed.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the company also implemented cultural changes, discrimination might be eliminated and the claim is justified.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the company only changed legal terms, discrimination is likely hidden by the arbitration and NDAs (Z), and the claim is not justified.

wise_refusal: The claim that the company has eliminated workplace discrimination is ambiguous due to GOODHART. We cannot determine whether discrimination has ceased or has merely been suppressed without knowing if internal complaint volumes also decreased. If internal complaints are also zero, the claim may be justified. If complaints persist but are hidden by NDAs and arbitration (Z), the zero public lawsuit count (Y) is a gamed metric. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: The metric (public lawsuits) was targeted (X). The company gamed it by changing the venue of dispute resolution (Z), severing the link between the metric and the underlying reality.
hidden_timestamp: Did the discrimination stop, or was it just moved to a private forum?

scenario: States with the highest number of lawyers per capita (X) consistently report the highest rates of civil litigation (Y). These states also tend to have much higher levels of urbanization and economic activity (Z). A tort reform advocate argues that 'greedy lawyers create lawsuits' and that restricting bar admissions will reduce the state's legal caseload.
claim: The presence of more lawyers causes more lawsuits.
label: NO
causal_structure: Urbanization (Z) drives both the concentration of lawyers (X) and the volume of legal disputes (Y).
key_insight: The aggregate correlation between lawyers and lawsuits may disappear when controlling for urbanization.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the correlation holds within subgroups of similar urbanization (Z), then lawyer density (X) may indeed drive litigation rates (Y).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the correlation disappears when looking at similarly urbanized areas (Z), the link is an ecological artifact of city size.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to the ECOLOGICAL trap. We cannot determine whether lawyers cause lawsuits or if both are driven by urbanization (Z) without knowing if the pattern holds within urbanization subgroups. If the pattern holds within subgroups, the causal claim might be valid. If it disappears, the correlation is merely an aggregation artifact. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: Urban and economically active states (Z) generate both more legal disputes (Y) and a higher demand for legal services (X). The aggregate correlation reflects this common cause, not necessarily a direct causal link.
hidden_timestamp: Does the pattern hold within each subgroup of urbanization (Z)?

scenario: A sociological study of divorce records reveals that fathers who are awarded sole custody after contentious litigation (X) are significantly more likely to see their children graduate from college (Y) compared to fathers with joint custody from amicable settlements. A Men's Rights advocacy group argues that the adversarial court process successfully identifies and empowers the most capable parents.
claim: The adversarial court process selects better parents.
label: NO
causal_structure: Highly motivated and wealthy fathers (Z) are the only ones willing/able to fight contentious custody battles (X) and also support children's education (Y).
key_insight: The sample of litigating fathers is selected for high motivation and resources.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If litigating fathers have similar baseline resources/motivation to settling fathers, the process may be effective.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If only wealthy or hyper-motivated fathers pursue litigation (Z), the outcome (Y) is driven by these pre-existing traits, not the court process.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to Selection Bias. We cannot determine whether the court process (X) creates better outcomes or simply selects for fathers who are already highly motivated and wealthy (Z). If the sample of sole-custody fathers is self-selected for high resource commitment, the better outcomes are likely due to those resources, not the litigation itself.
gold_rationale: Selection bias: Fathers who endure expensive, high-conflict custody battles (X) are not a random sample. They possess high motivation and financial resources (Z) that independently drive educational success (Y).
hidden_timestamp: Are fathers who pursue contentious litigation comparable to the general population of divorced fathers?

scenario: A large corporation notes that in the year since it mandated binding arbitration for all employee disputes (X), the average dollar amount awarded to winning employees (Y) is 20% higher than the average court judgment in previous years. The General Counsel claims this proves that arbitration is a more generous forum for workers than federal court.
claim: Arbitration results in higher payouts for employees.
label: NO
causal_structure: High upfront costs/risks of arbitration cause plaintiff attorneys to only file the strongest, highest-value cases (Z), leading to higher average awards (Y).
key_insight: The pool of cases in arbitration is filtered for high value; weak cases are dropped entirely.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the mix of cases in arbitration is identical to those in court, the forum may be more generous.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If plaintiff lawyers only bring 'slam dunk' high-value cases (Z) to arbitration to justify the cost/risk, the higher average (Y) reflects the case mix, not the forum's generosity.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to Selection Bias. We cannot determine if arbitration (X) is more generous without knowing if the case pool is comparable to court dockets. If attorneys only file the strongest, highest-value cases (Z) in arbitration while dropping weaker claims, the higher average award (Y) reflects the selection of cases, not the fairness of the forum.
gold_rationale: Selection bias (Censoring): We only observe awards for cases that are actually filed. If arbitration creates barriers to entry (Z), only high-value cases survive to the award stage, artificially inflating the average.
hidden_timestamp: Do the disputes filed in arbitration represent a random sample of all employee grievances?

scenario: Government data from 2020-2025 shows that holders of the 'EB-1 Extraordinary Ability' visa (X) have a near-zero felony arrest rate (Y), significantly lower than the native-born population. A Senator argues that this data proves that strict vetting works and that expanding the total number of immigrants—regardless of visa type—will reduce the national crime rate.
claim: Expanding immigration will reduce crime.
label: NO
causal_structure: The EB-1 visa criteria select for older, highly educated, wealthy individuals (Z), who statistically have low crime rates (Y) regardless of immigration status.
key_insight: EB-1 holders are a hyper-selected subgroup not representative of all immigrants.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If EB-1 holders are demographically similar to the general immigrant pool, the inference might hold.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If EB-1 holders are selected for high education/wealth (Z), their low crime rate (Y) cannot be generalized to other visa categories.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to Selection Bias. We cannot generalize the low crime rate of EB-1 holders (X) to the general immigrant population without knowing if they share the same demographic profile. If EB-1 visas select for high socioeconomic status and education (Z), the low crime rate (Y) is a function of those traits, not immigration status itself.
gold_rationale: The sample (EB-1 holders) is a non-representative subset of the target population (all immigrants). The selection criteria for the visa (Z) serve as a confounder for crime rates.
hidden_timestamp: Are EB-1 visa holders representative of the general applicant pool for other visa categories?

scenario: Insurance data shows neurosurgeons (X) are sued for malpractice (Y) 5x more often than dermatologists, though many medical errors do not result in catastrophic injury (Z). A newspaper concludes neurosurgeons are more negligent.
claim: Neurosurgeons are more negligent than other doctors.
label: NO
causal_structure: Lawsuits (Y) only happen when damages are severe enough to motivate legal action (Z). Neurosurgeons deal with high-stakes cases where bad outcomes are catastrophic.
key_insight: A lawsuit survives the 'cost-benefit' filter only if damages are high. Dermatologist errors (Z low) rarely motivate suits.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If minor errors don't trigger lawsuits, specialty risk (Z) confounds the suit rate.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If all errors are sued equally, the claim holds.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to SURVIVORSHIP bias. We cannot determine negligence levels without knowing the rate of minor errors that do not lead to lawsuits (Z). If minor errors are frequent but rarely result in suits in some specialties, then lawsuit rates do not reflect negligence. If all errors are sued equally across specialties, then the claim is justified. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: Selection on severity. Only severe outcomes 'survive' to become lawsuits.
hidden_timestamp: Do dermatologists make errors that result in minor, unsued injuries?

scenario: A study of employment arbitration cases (X) finds that employees win 60% of the time (Y). The arbitration industry argues this proves the system is fair to workers.
claim: Arbitration is fair to workers.
label: NO
causal_structure: Lawyers only take arbitration cases (X) on contingency if they are 'slam dunks' (Z) because payouts are low. Weaker but valid cases are dropped (attrition).
key_insight: The filed cases are the survivors of a rigorous selection process by plaintiffs' lawyers.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If lawyers reject 90% of potential cases due to low arbitration caps, the 60% win rate reflects only the strongest survivors.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If access to arbitration is easy for all, the rate reflects fairness.

wise_refusal: The 60% win rate applies only to cases that survive the initial filtering process (Z). Because arbitration often limits damages, lawyers may only accept 'sure winner' cases. Many valid but lower-value grievances may never be filed (attrition), making the system appear fairer than it is.
gold_rationale: The sample of 'arbitrated cases' is censored. It excludes cases that were priced out of the justice system.
hidden_timestamp: How many employees with valid grievances couldn't find a lawyer to take their case to arbitration?

scenario: A state passes a mandatory bicycle helmet law (X). The following year, the number of cyclists admitted to hospitals with head injuries (Y) actually increases. Opponents argue helmets make cycling more dangerous.
claim: Helmets increase the risk of head injury.
label: NO
causal_structure: Helmets convert deaths (invisible to hospital data) into injuries (visible Y). X increases Z, which increases Y.
key_insight: You have to survive to go to the hospital. Dead cyclists don't get admitted.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If fatalities dropped, the rise in injuries represents survivors who previously would have died.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If fatalities also rose, the law might have increased risk (e.g. risk compensation).

wise_refusal: The increase in hospital admissions likely reflects survivorship bias (Z). Helmets convert fatal accidents (which go to the morgue) into non-fatal injuries (which go to the hospital). The 'rise' in injuries is actually a rise in survivors.
gold_rationale: Classic Abraham Wald logic. The intervention moves people from the 'dead' category (unobserved in hospital data) to the 'injured' category (observed).
hidden_timestamp: Did the fatality rate drop while injuries rose?

scenario: Internal Affairs audits officers who receive more than 5 citizen complaints per year (Z). Within this audited group, officers with high arrest counts (X) have significantly fewer 'excessive force' complaints (Y) than officers with low arrest counts. The Chief concludes that active policing teaches restraint.
claim: High arrest activity causes a reduction in excessive force.
label: NO
causal_structure: Total Complaints (Z) = Arrest Complaints (from X) + Force Complaints (Y).
key_insight: In the high-complaint group, if the complaints didn't come from Force, they must have come from Arrest volume.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If complaints arise from both sources, the correlation is spurious.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If arrest volume never generates complaints, the correlation might be valid.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to a COLLIDER trap. We cannot determine whether high arrest activity reduces force complaints without knowing if complaints stem from both arrest volume and use of force. If complaints arise from both, the negative correlation is a spurious result of conditioning on the total complaint threshold (Z). If arrest volume does not generate complaints, the correlation might reflect a valid causal link. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: Conditioning on the sum (Total Complaints) induces a negative correlation between the addends (Arrest Complaints and Force Complaints).
hidden_timestamp: Do citizen complaints stem from both arrest volume (people disliking arrest) and use of force?

scenario: A study of cases where the defendant took the stand (Z) reveals that those who admitted to prior minor crimes (X) were acquitted (Y) more often than those who claimed a perfect past. A defense attorney advises clients that admitting to crimes builds credibility.
claim: Admitting to prior crimes increases the chance of acquittal.
label: NO
causal_structure: Defendants only testify (Z) if the benefit outweighs the risk of X.
key_insight: Defendants with prior crimes only take the stand if their innocence evidence is otherwise overwhelming.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If attorneys screen witnesses based on case strength, the correlation is spurious.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the decision to testify is random, the credibility argument might hold.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to a COLLIDER trap. We cannot determine whether admitting crimes increases acquittal chances without knowing if attorneys prevent defendants with priors from testifying unless the case is otherwise very strong. If attorneys screen witnesses (Z) based on case strength (Y), the correlation is a spurious result of strategic selection. If the decision to testify is random, the credibility argument might hold. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: Conditioning on the strategic decision to testify (Z) selects for high case strength (Y) whenever the negative factor (X) is present.
hidden_timestamp: Do defense attorneys prevent defendants with priors from testifying unless the case is otherwise very strong?

scenario: Under a strict points-based immigration system (Z), admitted immigrants with no university degree (X) earn significantly higher wages (Y) than admitted immigrants with PhDs. A policymaker argues that education is inversely correlated with economic success for immigrants.
claim: Lower education causes higher earnings for immigrants.
label: NO
causal_structure: Admission (Z) requires Education (not X) OR High Income (Y).
key_insight: To get in without a degree, you need a massive salary to meet the points threshold.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If points are additive (Education + Income > Threshold), the correlation is spurious.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If admission is random, the correlation reflects a real economic phenomenon.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to a COLLIDER trap. We cannot determine whether lower education causes higher earnings without knowing if the points system (Z) allows high income (Y) to offset low education (X). If points are additive, then the correlation is a spurious result of selection. If admission is independent of these factors, the correlation might reflect a real phenomenon. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: Conditioning on Z (Total Points > T) where Points = Education + Income induces a negative correlation between Education and Income.
hidden_timestamp: Does the points system allow high income to offset low education?

scenario: A study of politicians who survived major scandals (Z) found they were viewed as more charismatic (X) but also more corrupt (Y) than politicians who resigned. A pundit claims that charisma leads to corruption.
claim: Charismatic politicians are more likely to be corrupt.
label: NO
causal_structure: Survival (Z) depends on Charisma (X) vs Corruption Severity (Y).
key_insight: Only charismatic politicians can survive severe corruption scandals.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If survival requires Charisma > Scandal Severity, the correlation is spurious.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If survival is unrelated to charisma, the correlation might be real.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to a COLLIDER trap. We cannot determine whether charisma leads to corruption without knowing if survival (Z) depends on a trade-off where charisma (X) must offset corruption severity (Y). If survival requires high charisma to survive high corruption, the correlation is a spurious result of survivorship bias. If survival is unrelated to charisma, the correlation might be real. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: Conditioning on survival (Z) creates a positive correlation between the 'threat' (Corruption) and the 'defense' (Charisma).
hidden_timestamp: Did the politicians survive (Z) because of their charisma (X) despite the corruption (Y)?

scenario: An IRS audit of flagged tax returns (Z) finds that low-income filers (X) have a higher rate of tax evasion (Y) than high-income filers. A politician uses this to argue that the poor are less honest.
claim: Low-income filers are more likely to evade taxes than high-income filers.
label: NO
causal_structure: Audit (Z) is caused by Suspicious Patterns (Y) OR Random High-Income Checks (not X).
key_insight: High-income earners might be audited randomly; low-income earners are usually audited only for cause.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If low-income audits are purely trigger-based and high-income audits include random sweeps, the comparison is biased.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If audit criteria are uniform and random, the finding stands.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to a COLLIDER trap. We cannot determine if low income leads to evasion without knowing if the audit selection (Z) criteria differ by income level (X). If low-income filers are only audited when there is strong evidence of evasion (Y) while others are audited randomly, the finding is biased by selection. If audit criteria are uniform, the correlation may be real. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: Differential selection into the sample (Z). Low income + Audit => Likely Evasion. High Income + Audit => Could be random.
hidden_timestamp: Is the audit selection criteria different for different income groups?

scenario: A study of patent lawsuits (Z) finds that patents with very few citations (X) are upheld as valid (Y) at a higher rate than highly cited patents. A researcher argues that citations are a sign of 'obviousness' and thus lower validity.
claim: Low citations cause higher patent validity.
label: NO
causal_structure: Litigation (Z) occurs when value is high (often correlated with X) AND validity is uncertain.
key_insight: Highly cited (valuable) patents with clear validity are settled, not litigated. Low cited patents are only litigated if they are surprisingly strong.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If strong/valuable patents settle, the litigated sample is biased.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If litigation is random, the correlation reflects true quality.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to a COLLIDER trap. We cannot determine if low citations cause higher validity without knowing if the decision to litigate (Z) is based on the patent's perceived strength (Y) and value (X). If valuable patents with clear validity settle out of court to avoid risk, then the litigated sample is biased toward low-cited patents with surprisingly high validity. If litigation is random, the correlation may be real. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: Conditioning on Litigation (Z) filters out cases where the outcome is clear or the value is high enough to force settlement.
hidden_timestamp: Did the parties decide to settle or litigate based on the patent's perceived strength?

scenario: Traffic stops where a breathalyzer was administered (Z) show that drivers who were driving perfectly (X) had higher Blood Alcohol Content (Y) on average than drivers who were swerving. A police union rep argues that swerving is not a good indicator of drunk driving.
claim: Perfect driving is associated with higher drunkenness among stopped drivers.
label: NO
causal_structure: Test (Z) requires Swerving (not X) OR Other Signs like smell/slurring (Y).
key_insight: If a driver was driving perfectly (X), there must have been another strong reason (High Y) to test them.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If tests are based on cumulative suspicion, the correlation is spurious.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If tests are random (checkpoints), the correlation is real.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to a COLLIDER trap. We cannot determine whether perfect driving is associated with higher drunkenness without knowing if the decision to administer a breathalyzer (Z) is based on a combination of driving behavior (X) and other physical signs (Y). If tests are based on cumulative suspicion, then the correlation is a spurious result of selection. If tests are conducted at random checkpoints, the correlation might reflect a real association. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: Classic Berkson's. Z = (Not X) OR Y. If Z=1 and X=1 (Perfect driving), then Y MUST be 1.
hidden_timestamp: Was the breathalyzer administered based on driving behavior or other physical signs?

scenario: Government data shows that Naturalized Citizens (X) have a significantly lower felony conviction rate (Y) than Permanent Residents (Green Card holders). A senator argues that the naturalization civic test instills better moral character.
claim: The naturalization process reduces criminal behavior.
label: NO
causal_structure: Naturalization requires a clean record (Z) during the waiting period; criminals are screened out.
key_insight: You must avoid crime for 3-5 years to enter the 'Naturalized' group.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the comparison controls for the screening period, the effect might be real.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If it simply compares groups, the naturalization group is selected for past law-abiding behavior.

wise_refusal: This is a classic immortal time bias. To become a Naturalized Citizen, a resident must maintain a clean record for 3-5 years. Any Permanent Resident who commits a felony is disqualified from the 'Naturalized' group. The lower crime rate is a prerequisite for the status, not necessarily a result of it.
gold_rationale: Immortal time bias: Naturalization (X) requires maintaining a clean criminal record (Y=0) during a mandatory 3-5 year waiting period. The lower conviction rate is a prerequisite for achieving the status, rather than a causal effect of the process itself.
hidden_timestamp: Does the data account for the mandatory waiting period where crime prevents naturalization?

scenario: A basketball player had a record-breaking rookie season (Z), averaging 30 points per game. Based on this, he signed a lucrative endorsement deal with a 'performance clause' (X). In his second season, his average dropped to 22 points (Y). The sponsor sued to void the contract, claiming the player stopped trying after getting paid.
claim: The guaranteed money caused the player's performance to decline.
label: NO
causal_structure: The contract (X) was awarded after an outlier performance (Z). An outlier season is typically followed by a season closer to the player's true average (Y), regardless of incentives.
key_insight: Exceptional performances are rarely sustainable; decline is statistical, not necessarily behavioral.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the rookie season was a statistical outlier, the decline (Y) is Regression to the Mean (Z).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the player's performance was consistent with his long-term talent, the decline (Y) might be caused by the contract (X).

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to REGRESSION. We cannot determine whether the decline (Y) was caused by the contract (X) or the 'Sophomore Slump' (Z) without knowing the player's historical consistency. If the rookie year was a massive outlier, the decline is likely statistical regression. If the player was previously consistent, the decline might be behavioral. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: Classic 'Sophomore Slump'. The contract was awarded based on an extreme value (record season). The subsequent decline is a return to the mean, not necessarily a result of the financial incentive.
hidden_timestamp: Was the rookie season consistent with his pre-professional career, or a massive outlier?

scenario: Highways with posted speed limits of 70 mph (X) have fewer accidents per mile (Y) than residential roads with speed limits of 30 mph. These roads differ in Road Design (Z), with highways being engineered for safety. A drivers' rights group argues that raising speed limits on all roads will improve safety.
claim: Higher speed limits cause fewer accidents.
label: NO
causal_structure: High speed limits are applied to limited-access highways (Z) which are engineered for safety. Complex residential roads (Z') require low limits.
key_insight: Speed limits are set based on road safety, not the other way around.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If raising limits on residential roads increases accidents, the aggregate correlation is an ecological fallacy.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If higher limits reduce accidents on residential roads, the causal claim would be supported.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to the ECOLOGICAL trap. We cannot determine whether higher limits cause safety without knowing if the pattern holds within specific road designs (Z). If raising limits on residential roads increases accidents, then the aggregate correlation is misleading. If it decreases them, the claim is justified. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: The correlation is driven by road engineering (Z). Safer roads get higher limits. Transferring the limit without the engineering ignores the causal mechanism of safety.
hidden_timestamp: Does the relationship between speed limits (X) and accident rates (Y) hold within each road design category (Z)?

scenario: A legal study finds that defendants of high socioeconomic status (Z) who wear expensive, tailored suits (X) to court are acquitted (Y) 30% more often than defendants who wear casual clothes. A defense attorney advises his indigent client to spend his last savings on an Armani suit to guarantee an acquittal.
claim: Wearing an expensive suit causes higher acquittal rates.
label: NO
causal_structure: Wealth (Z) allows for both expensive suits (X) and high-quality legal defense, which leads to acquittal (Y).
key_insight: The suit is a marker of resources, not the cause of the verdict.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If wealth (Z) is the primary driver of both suit choice and legal defense quality, then the suit itself is merely a correlate and does not cause acquittal.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the suit (X) directly biases jury perception regardless of the quality of legal representation, then wearing the suit has a direct causal effect on acquittal.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to CONFOUNDER. We cannot determine whether the suit itself influences the verdict or if the result is driven by socioeconomic status (Z) without knowing if defendants with similar legal resources see the same benefit. If wealth drives both suit choice and defense quality, then the suit is just a correlate. If the suit biases the jury independent of defense quality, then it is causal. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: Socioeconomic status (Z) is a common cause for both the ability to purchase expensive attire (X) and the ability to hire effective legal counsel, which drives the acquittal (Y).
hidden_timestamp: Is there an unmeasured common cause Z, such as socioeconomic status, that influences both the choice of attire (X) and the quality of legal representation that leads to acquittal (Y)?

scenario: A city implemented bail reform (X). Six months later, the violent crime rate (Y) spiked. Police unions blame the release of defendants. Data shows the city also suffered a massive economic collapse (Z) that same month.
claim: Bail reform caused the crime spike.
label: NO
causal_structure: The economic collapse (Z) is a sufficient cause for crime (Y), making the effect of X ambiguous.
key_insight: A major external shock coincided with the policy change.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If crime rose in similar cities without bail reform, the economy (Z) is the likely cause.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If crime only rose in the reform city, the policy (X) may be responsible.

wise_refusal: The crime spike is confounded by the simultaneous economic collapse (Z). Economic distress is a known driver of crime (Y). Without a control group that experienced the collapse without the reform, we cannot attribute the rise to bail policy.
gold_rationale: The co-occurring economic shock (Z) confounds the relationship between the policy (X) and the outcome (Y).
hidden_timestamp: Did crime rates rise in jurisdictions with the collapse (Z) but no bail reform?
