scenario: A city mandated that all bicyclists wear high-visibility vests (X). This led to a significant increase in the public perception of cycling as a high-risk activity (Y). Analysts found that as bicycing was perceived as more dangerous (Y), cyclists felt even more compelled to wear high-visibility gear (X) and adopt aggressive defensive riding (Z) on sidewalks, which in turn reinforced the public image of cycling as an inherently unsafe mode of transport (Y).
claim: The increased usage of high-visibility vests (X) is the primary cause of the heightened public perception of risk (Y).
label: NO
causal_structure: X <-> Y

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If a reinforcing loop exists where the perception of risk (Y) also drives vest usage (X), then the claim of unidirectional causation is incomplete as both variables reinforce each other.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If no reinforcing loop exists and the perception of risk (Y) has no effect on vest usage (X), then the claim that X caused Y is justified.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to Feedback. We cannot determine whether a reinforcing loop exists between vest usage (X) and perceived risk (Y) or if causation is unidirectional from X to Y without knowing if perceived risk (Y) also influences vest adoption (X). If a reinforcing loop exists, then X and Y are mutually reinforcing and the claim of simple unidirectional causation is not justified. If causation is unidirectional, then the claim that X caused Y is justified. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
key_insight: Safety interventions can reinforce the very perception of danger they aim to mitigate.
gold_rationale: In a feedback loop, the outcome (Y) feeds back into the exposure (X). Here, the mandate (X) increases the perception of danger (Y), which in turn makes cyclists more likely to adhere to or demand safety gear (X). This bidirectional relationship makes it impossible to attribute the correlation to a single causal direction without further longitudinal data on the loop's dynamics.
hidden_timestamp: Is there a reinforcing loop between vest usage (X) and perceived risk (Y)?

scenario: A county implemented a system of commission-based property tax assessments (X) in districts that were already experiencing double the national average in assessment rates (Y). The private assessment firm (Z) claims that their specialized auditing methods (X) are responsible for the exceptionally high revenue (Y).
claim: The commission-based incentives (X) given to the firm (Z) caused the high tax assessment rates (Y).
label: NO
causal_structure: Claimed: X -> Y; Actual: Y -> X

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the tax assessment rates (Y) were initially normal and only doubled after the commission-based firm (X) was hired, the claim that X causes Y is supported.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the rates (Y) were already high and the county hired the firm (Z) on commission (X) as a reactive policy to manage the existing high-value roll, then Y preceded X and the claim is not justified.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to REVERSE causation. We cannot determine whether the commission-based incentives (X) caused the high rates or if the high rates (Y) led to the policy without knowing the temporal order of events. If Y rose after X, then X may be the cause. If Y was already high and led to the adoption of X, then the claim is not justified. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
key_insight: Incentive policies are often implemented as reactions to existing high-value metrics.
gold_rationale: This case demonstrates a 'reactive policy' trap where the outcome (Y) likely preceded and caused the adoption of the treatment (X). The correlation is driven by the fact that the commission-based system was targeted at districts that already exhibited the outcome of interest.
hidden_timestamp: Did the high tax assessment rates (Y) precede the implementation of the commission-based incentives (X)?

scenario: Universities with honor codes (X) report lower levels of cheating (Y). While some claim the code (X) is the cause, critics suggest that schools that have already achieved low cheating rates (Y) due to high student integrity (Z) are simply more likely to adopt an honor code (X) as a formal recognition of their culture.
claim: Adopting an honor code (X) will cause cheating (Y) to decrease.
label: NO
causal_structure: Either X -> Y or Z -> Y -> X

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the honor code (X) was implemented before the low cheating rates (Y) were observed, then the code may have had a causal effect on reducing cheating.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the low cheating rates (Y) and high integrity (Z) were already present before the honor code (X) was adopted, then the code is likely a consequence of the existing culture.

wise_refusal: The claim that honor codes (X) cause low cheating (Y) is ambiguous due to REVERSE causation. We cannot determine whether the code reduced cheating or if low cheating prompted the code without knowing if the behavior preceded the policy (Z). If the code (X) was adopted first and cheating (Y) decreased, then $X 	o Y$ is plausible. If low cheating (Y) and integrity (Z) were already present before the code, then $Y 	o X$. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
key_insight: It is unclear if the policy creates the culture or if the pre-existing culture drives the policy adoption.
gold_rationale: Causality is ambiguous because schools with low cheating (Y) and high integrity (Z) are more likely to adopt honor codes (X). Without knowing whether the code preceded the low cheating rates, we cannot distinguish between the code as a cause ($X 	o Y$) or as a consequence of the existing behavior ($Y 	o X$).
hidden_timestamp: Did the low cheating rates (Y) exist before the honor code (X) was adopted?

scenario: A financial services company launched a new credit monitoring app (X). A year later, they observed that users of the app had significantly higher credit scores (Y) than non-users. They also noted that these users had a lower debt-to-income ratio (Z) compared to the start of the study period.
claim: Using the credit monitoring app (X) improved credit scores (Y) by helping users achieve a lower debt-to-income ratio (Z).
label: NO
causal_structure: Either Z -> X and Z -> Y (Confounder) or X -> Z -> Y (Mediator)

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the debt reduction (Z) occurred before app usage (X), then Z is a confounder reflecting pre-existing financial responsibility that drove both app adoption and credit score improvements, making the claim unjustified.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the debt reduction (Z) occurred after app usage (X), then Z is a mediator and the app likely facilitated the debt reduction which in turn improved credit scores, making the claim justified.

wise_refusal: The claim that the credit monitoring app (X) improved credit scores (Y) via debt reduction (Z) is ambiguous due to Confounder-Mediator Ambiguity (T9). We cannot determine whether debt reduction was a cause or an effect of the app usage without knowing whether the reduction (Z) began before or after the users started using the app (X). If Z occurred before X, then it is a confounder and the claim is not justified. If Z occurred after X, then it is a mediator and the claim is justified. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
key_insight: Temporal order determines whether a correlated factor is a mechanism of a policy or a source of selection bias.
gold_rationale: The scenario presents an ambiguity between a mediation model (X -> Z -> Y) and a confounding model (X <- Z -> Y). If the users were already improving their financial situation (Z) before adopting the app (X), then the app is simply a marker of a responsible user group. If the improvement followed the app usage, the app's features likely caused the change. Without temporal data, we cannot distinguish these causal structures.
hidden_timestamp: Did the reduction in debt-to-income ratio (Z) occur before or after the users began using the credit monitoring app (X)?

scenario: A tech giant predominantly hires candidates who completed 'Elite Coding Bootcamps' (X). The company claims that the hiring decision (Y) is justified because these candidates achieve much higher scores on 'Technical Interview Evaluations' (Z). Advocacy groups point out that wealthy individuals might already have the resources to be highly skilled before even starting a bootcamp.
claim: The Elite Coding Bootcamps (X) are the primary cause of high technical interview scores (Z), which in turn lead to better hiring outcomes (Y).
label: NO
causal_structure: Either Z (pre-existing) -> X and Z -> Y, or X -> Z -> Y

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the technical interview scores (Z) were high before the bootcamp (X) (tz < tx), then Z is a confounder, and the bootcamp itself may not be the primary cause of the hiring success.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the high technical interview scores (Z) were achieved only after the bootcamp (X) (tx < tz), then Z is a mediator, and the bootcamp likely caused the improvement in hiring outcomes.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to CONF-MED. We cannot determine whether high technical interview scores (Z) are a confounder or a mediator without knowing if the candidates' scores (Z) were high before the bootcamp (X) (tz < tx) or after (tx < tz). If tz < tx, then Z is a confounder reflecting pre-existing skill that leads to both X and Y. If tx < tz, then Z is a mediator through which the bootcamp (X) improves hiring prospects (Y). Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
key_insight: Pre-existing traits can be mistaken for effects of an intervention without temporal data.
gold_rationale: The relationship between X and Y is mediated or confounded by Z depending on the temporal order. If Z precedes X, it indicates selection bias (skilled people choose bootcamps). If X precedes Z, it indicates a causal mechanism. The timing of Z is the pivotal information.
hidden_timestamp: Did the candidates' high technical interview scores (Z) exist before they enrolled in the bootcamps (X), or did the bootcamps (X) produce those scores (Z)?

scenario: A city increased its minimum wage (X). Subsequently, regional employment (Y) rose by 5%. City officials also observed a significant rise in local consumer spending power (Z) during the same period.
claim: The minimum wage increase (X) drove the 5% employment rise (Y) by increasing local consumer spending power (Z).
label: NO
causal_structure: Either Z -> X and Z -> Y (Confounder) or X -> Z -> Y (Mediator)

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the increase in spending power (Z) occurred before the wage hike (X), then Z is a confounder representing a broader economic recovery that enabled both the wage increase and the job growth, making the claim unjustified.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the increase in spending power (Z) occurred after the wage hike (X), then Z is a mediator through which the higher wages stimulated the local economy and boosted employment, making the claim justified.

wise_refusal: The claim that the minimum wage hike (X) increased employment (Y) via consumer spending (Z) is ambiguous due to Confounder-Mediator Ambiguity (T9). We cannot determine whether spending power was a cause or an effect of the policy without knowing if the increase (Z) preceded or followed the hike (X). If Z occurred before X, it is a confounder and the claim is not justified. If Z occurred after X, it is a mediator and the claim is justified. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
key_insight: Economic indicators can be drivers of policy changes or the intended results of those policies.
gold_rationale: The scenario describes a situation where an economic shift (Z) could either be the mechanism of the policy (X -> Z -> Y) or a confounding factor (X <- Z -> Y). If the economy was already improving and spending was up before the hike, the hike cannot be credited with the outcome. If the spending surge followed the hike, the causal chain is plausible. Temporal data is required to resolve this.
hidden_timestamp: Did the increase in local consumer spending power (Z) occur before or after the minimum wage hike (X) was implemented?

scenario: A state government reduced environmental regulations (X) for the mining industry. Over the following years, state tax revenue (Y) from mining activities increased. During this same period, there was a significant increase in private investment in the state's mining sector (Z).
claim: Reducing environmental regulations (X) increased state revenue (Y) by attracting more private investment (Z).
label: NO
causal_structure: Either Z -> X and Z -> Y (Confounder) or X -> Z -> Y (Mediator)

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the investment surge (Z) occurred before the regulatory reduction (X), then Z is a confounder reflecting a market boom that drove both the lobbying for deregulation and the revenue increase, making the claim unjustified.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the investment surge (Z) occurred after the regulatory reduction (X), then Z is a mediator through which the policy change attracted capital and boosted revenue, making the claim justified.

wise_refusal: The claim that reducing regulations (X) increased revenue (Y) via investment (Z) is ambiguous due to Confounder-Mediator Ambiguity (T9). We cannot determine whether investment was a cause or an effect of the policy without knowing if the surge (Z) preceded or followed the reduction (X). If Z occurred before X, then it is a confounder and the claim is not justified. If Z occurred after X, then it is a mediator and the claim is justified. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
key_insight: Market-driven booms can precede and trigger deregulation, creating a false appearance of policy success.
gold_rationale: This case tests the ability to distinguish between a policy causing an investment boom (mediation) and an investment boom causing a policy shift (confounding). If the capital was already flowing in before the laws changed, the deregulated environment cannot be the primary cause of the revenue growth. Temporal data on when the investment began relative to the policy announcement is the key missing information.
hidden_timestamp: Did the increase in private mining investment (Z) occur before or after the regulatory reduction (X) was announced?

scenario: A law firm allows associates to volunteer for a 'Pro Bono' bonus program (X). Associates who choose to participate (X) have significantly higher retention rates (Y). A struggling firm concludes that the program causes associates to stay longer, even though the decision to participate is driven by pre-existing firm loyalty (Z).
claim: Introducing a pro bono bonus will cause associate retention to increase.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z (Loyalty) -> X (Participation) and Z -> Y (Retention)

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the pro bono program (X) itself keeps people, then introducing it would cause retention (Y) to increase.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If only loyal associates (Z) volunteer for the program, then the high retention reflects pre-existing loyalty rather than the effect of the bonus.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to Selection bias (T1). We cannot determine whether the program increases retention or if loyal associates are simply more likely to participate without knowing the participants' pre-existing loyalty (Z). If the program itself is the cause, retention would increase. If only loyal associates (Z) participate, the retention (Y) reflects that loyalty. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
key_insight: Volunteer programs often attract those already committed to the organization.
gold_rationale: High retention (Y) is likely the result of a healthy overall firm culture and strong management (Z), which also happens to implement pro bono incentives (X). Simply adding a bonus (X) in a firm with poor management or toxic culture (Z) will likely fail to fix the retention problem.
hidden_timestamp: Are associates with low pre-existing loyalty (Z) systematically excluded from the group that participates in the pro bono program (X)?

scenario: A facial recognition algorithm matches a suspect (X) to a security video. The prosecution claims this proves the suspect is the person in the video (Y). However, the algorithm's error rate is known to depend heavily on the lighting conditions (Z) of the source image.
claim: The suspect is the person in the video.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z -> Error Rate of X -> Y

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the lighting conditions were optimal (Z), the algorithm has a near-zero false positive rate. The match (X) likely indicates the suspect is the person in the video (Y).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the lighting conditions were poor (Z), the algorithm produces frequent false positives. The match (X) is unreliable and does not justify concluding the suspect is the person in the video (Y).

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to Measurement Bias (T13). We cannot determine whether the match is reliable without knowing the lighting conditions (Z). If the lighting was optimal, the identification is likely correct. If the lighting was poor, the match may be a statistical error. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
key_insight: Measurement accuracy can vary significantly across different subgroups or conditions (Z).
gold_rationale: Facial recognition systems often exhibit differential error rates based on environmental factors like lighting (Z). Without knowing Z, we cannot interpret the reliability of the match (X) as evidence for identity (Y).
hidden_timestamp: Were the lighting conditions (Z) optimal during the scan?

scenario: Countries with strict 'Good Samaritan' laws (X) report high rates of volunteerism (Y). A legal scholar argues that the law (X) causes people to be more helpful (Y). However, critics note that these jurisdictions often have a long-standing altruistic political culture (Z) that already promoted high engagement.
claim: The adoption of 'Good Samaritan' laws (X) causes an increase in volunteerism (Y).

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If volunteerism (Y) was already high due to the underlying culture (Z) and led to the passage of the law (X) as a reactive policy, then Y preceded X and the claim is not justified.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to REVERSE causation. We cannot determine whether the 'Good Samaritan' law (X) causes volunteerism or if high volunteerism (Y) led to the passage of the law without knowing the temporal order of events. If Y rose after X, then X may cause Y. If Y was already high and led to the adoption of X, then the claim is not justified. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
key_insight: Laws are often artifacts of existing social behavior rather than creators of it.
gold_rationale: The correlation is likely driven by a reactive policy where high levels of existing volunteerism (Y) and an altruistic culture (Z) create political pressure to pass protective laws (X). Without temporal evidence, we cannot distinguish this from the claimed X -> Y effect.

scenario: A university implemented a mandatory 'Academic Integrity' software (X). Plagiarism cases dropped by 25% (Y). conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If awareness (Z) increased before the software implementation (tz < tx), then Z is a confounder (likely due to an external event), and the software (X) might not be the cause of the drop.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If awareness (Z) increased after the software implementation (tx < tz), then Z is a mediator caused by the software (e.g., via mandatory tutorials), which supports the causal claim.

If awareness (Z) rose before the software (tz < tx), then Z is a confounder and the software's impact is unproven. If awareness (Z) rose after the software (tx < tz), then the software likely caused the awareness which reduced plagiarism. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
key_insight: Temporal sequence determines if a variable is a common cause or a mechanism.
gold_rationale: The relationship between the software (X) and the drop in plagiarism (Y) is confounded by the ambiguity of student awareness (Z). If Z was already rising, it is a confounder; if it rose because of X, it is a mediator. Without temporal data, we cannot distinguish between these two structures.

scenario: A transportation department installed smart traffic lights (X) and traffic accidents fell by 15% (Y). Simultaneously, city-wide traffic data showed a significant increase in driver attentiveness (Z) on that boulevard. The city claims the smart lights made the road safer.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If attentiveness (Z) rose after the lights (tx < tz), then the lights likely caused the safety improvement by making drivers more engaged, supporting the claim.

If attentiveness rose before (tz < tx), Z is a confounder and the claim is unproven. If it rose after (tx < tz), the lights likely caused the improvement via Z. scenario: A sales executive filed a sexual harassment report (X) and was put on a Performance Improvement Plan (Z) two days later, eventually leading to termination (Y). conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the performance issues (Z) only appeared in the record after the report (X) was filed, then Z is likely a pretext for retaliation caused by X.

We cannot determine whether the performance issues (Z) were a legitimate reason or a pretext without knowing if they were documented before or after the harassment report (X). If the issues were documented before the report, then the termination (Y) may be legitimate. If they only appeared after the report, then the PIP (Z) is likely a pretext for retaliation. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
