scenario: In a residential complex of 500 units, 4 children in the same building wing developed a rare allergy (Y). The parents sue the building management for recent carpet cleaning (X). The allergy rate in that wing is 20x the national average, but critics argue this is a post-hoc cluster resulting from random distribution (Z).
claim: The carpet cleaning (X) caused the allergy cluster (Y).
causal_structure: X -> Y vs. Random clustering (Z)

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the building wing was selected for study prior to the discovery of the cases, the cluster (Y) may be statistically significant evidence of a link to X.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the boundary (Z) was drawn around the specific units only after the allergies were reported, the cluster is likely a random artifact of selection.

wise_refusal: The claim that carpet cleaning caused the allergy cluster is ambiguous due to T1: SELECTION. We cannot determine whether the cluster is significant or a statistical artifact without knowing if the 'wing' boundary was defined before or after the cases occurred. If the boundary was pre-defined, then the cluster (Y) may indicate causation. If the boundary was drawn post-hoc around the cases (Z), then the cluster is likely random noise. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
key_insight: Post-hoc definitions of sample boundaries create the illusion of causality through random clustering.
gold_rationale: Statistical significance depends on whether the hypothesis was formulated before or after data collection. A post-hoc cluster (Texas Sharpshooter) is a selection effect that cannot justify a causal claim.
label: NO
hidden_timestamp: Was the 'wing' boundary (Z) defined as a specific area of concern before the allergy cases (Y) were identified?

scenario: A tech company notes that 8 out of 10 major server crashes (Y) occurred on a Tuesday. The IT manager blames Tuesday-specific maintenance (X), even though the same maintenance occurs daily. Critics suggest the 'Tuesday' pattern is merely a statistical artifact of post-hoc grouping (Z).
claim: Tuesday maintenance (X) causes the server crashes (Y).
causal_structure: X -> Y vs. Random temporal clustering (Z)

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If there is a unique process running only on Tuesdays, the temporal link (Y) might be real.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If maintenance is identical every day and 'Tuesday' was only identified because it happened to have the most crashes, the pattern is likely noise (Z).

wise_refusal: The claim that Tuesday maintenance causes the crashes is ambiguous due to T1: SELECTION. We cannot determine whether the pattern is a causal link or a statistical artifact without knowing if the Tuesday hypothesis was formed before or after looking at the data. If there is a Tuesday-specific mechanism, then the link may be real. If the day was selected post-hoc (Z), then the pattern is likely random. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
key_insight: In small samples, random events will cluster on specific days by chance; selecting the cluster after the fact is a selection fallacy.
gold_rationale: Causal attribution requires a pre-specified hypothesis or a distinct mechanism. Without these, a temporal cluster is statistically indistinguishable from random noise.
label: NO
hidden_timestamp: Was 'Tuesday' hypothesized as a risk factor before the crash data (Y) was analyzed?

scenario: A law firm recruits 50% of its associates from 'Tier 1' law schools (X) but only 5% from 'Tier 3' schools. The firm argues that Tier 1 graduates have significantly higher 'professional readiness' (Z). Critics argue that this readiness (Z) is actually why they were admitted to Tier 1 schools in the first place.
claim: Attending a Tier 1 law school (X) causes an increase in professional readiness (Z), which leads to higher hiring rates (Y).
label: NO
causal_structure: Either Z -> X,Y (Confounder) or X -> Z -> Y (Mediator)

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If students were already professionally ready (tz < tx) due to pre-existing advantages, then Z is a confounder, and the school (X) is merely a marker for those traits.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the readiness (Z) was built by the Tier 1 school's unique resources (tx < tz), then the school is a cause of the hiring success via the mediator Z.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to CONF-MED. We cannot determine whether Tier 1 schools (X) cause readiness (Z) without knowing when that readiness appeared. If students were ready before admission (tz < tx), the school is a confounder and the claim is unproven. If they became ready because of the school (tx < tz), the school is a cause via Z. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
key_insight: A mediator is an effect of the cause; a confounder is a cause of the cause.
gold_rationale: The relationship between school prestige and hiring is confounded by readiness. If readiness is a pre-existing selection criterion for the school, it is a confounder. If it is an educational output, it is a mediator. Temporal data on when students acquired these skills is required.
hidden_timestamp: Did the high professional readiness (Z) manifest before the students entered the Tier 1 law schools (tz < tx) or was it developed as a result of the Tier 1 education (tx < tz)?

scenario: A digital fingerprint scan from a restricted server matches an employee (X). The vendor claims the software has a random match probability of 1 in 500,000. Depending on the employee pool size (Z), the security manager concludes there is a 99.9998% chance the employee accessed the server.
claim: Based on the 1-in-500,000 random match probability, it is 'more likely than not' (probability > 50%) that the employee is the individual who accessed the server.
label: NO
causal_structure: P(Match|Innocent) != P(Innocent|Match)

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the employee was a specific suspect from a small pool (Z), probability is high.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the match came from trawling a massive database (Z), the probability of guilt is low due to false positives.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to T2: SURVIVORSHIP. We cannot determine the probability of guilt without knowing how big the database searched was. If the employee was a specific suspect from a small pool (Z), then the probability is high. If the match came from trawling a massive database (Z), then the probability of guilt is low due to expected false positives. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
key_insight: Database trawling generates false positives.
gold_rationale: The claim is ambiguous because the posterior probability—the probability of guilt given a match, $P(Guilt|Match)$—cannot be determined without knowing the size of the suspect pool ($N$) or the prior probability of guilt. If the employee was one of only 10 people with access to the building, the probability of guilt is extremely high. However, if the match was found by searching a database of 1,000,000 people, we would expect at least two random matches, making the probability of this specific employee's guilt roughly 33% or 50% depending on other factors. Without observing the search context, the claim is underdetermined.
hidden_timestamp: How big was the database searched?

scenario: A state university's total enrollment (Y) spiked after offering free tuition (X). The board notes that enrollment depends on both new admits and graduation rates (Z). They argue that capping new admissions (X') will immediately return enrollment to previous levels.
claim: The total student enrollment (Y) in the upcoming academic year will be lower than the current year's enrollment if the university caps new admissions (X').
label: NO
causal_structure: Y_next = Y_now + Inflow(X) - Outflow(Z)

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the number of students graduating (Z) exceeds the number of new admits, then total enrollment (Y) will decrease.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the number of new admits remains higher than the number of graduates, then total enrollment (Y) will continue to rise, albeit at a slower rate.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to T15: MECHANISM. We cannot determine if enrollment (Y) will fall without knowing if graduation outflow (Z) exceeds the new admission inflow (X'). If outflow is greater, then enrollment will fall. If inflow is greater, then enrollment will rise. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
key_insight: A stock only decreases if the outflow is greater than the inflow.
gold_rationale: Total enrollment (Y) is a stock. Capping new admissions (X') only changes the inflow rate. Whether the total stock decreases depends on the balance between the new inflow and the existing outflow (graduation). Without data on graduation rates (Z), the direction of the change in Y is unknown.
hidden_timestamp: Is the number of graduating students (Z) larger than the number of students admitted under the new cap (X')?

scenario: A program sends disruptive students to spend a weekend in a high-security youth detention center (X) to deter them from crime. Longitudinal data shows these students had 20% higher arrest rates (Y) than a control group, as exposure led to peer contagion (Z) and the normalization of criminal behavior.
claim: The detention center experience (X) is an effective deterrent for disruptive students.
label: NO
causal_structure: X -> Z -> Y

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If detention center exposure (X) does not lead to peer contagion (Z), then the experience might act as a deterrent.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the exposure (X) triggers peer contagion (Z), then the program backfires and increases future arrest rates (Y).

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to Backfire. We cannot determine whether the program is effective or harmful without knowing if it triggered compensatory peer contagion (Z). If it did not, the experience (X) could deter crime. If it did (Z), students likely adopted deviant behaviors, leading to higher arrest rates (Y). Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
key_insight: Aggregating risk creates contagion.
gold_rationale: Evidence suggests 'Scared Straight' style programs often backfire. The mechanism is likely peer contagion or the normalization of criminal identity (Z), which socializes at-risk youth into a deviant subculture.
hidden_timestamp: Could the intervention (X) trigger compensatory behavior (Z)?

scenario: The number of active civil lawsuits (Y) grew after a law allowed 'No-Win, No-Fee' contracts (X). These cases typically involve long adjudication times (Z). A politician claims that banning these contracts (X') will immediately clear the backlogs.
claim: Banning 'No-Win, No-Fee' contracts (X') will immediately reduce the number of active lawsuits (Y).
label: NO
causal_structure: X -> Inflow; Y = Stock; Z = Outflow delay

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the ban is retroactive and requires dismissal of current cases, then the number of active lawsuits (Y) will drop immediately.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the ban only applies to new filings, the active count (Y) will remain high until existing cases are resolved over the usual adjudication time (Z).

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to T15: MECHANISM. We cannot determine the immediate effect without knowing if the ban (X') is retroactive. If it is retroactive, then Y will fall immediately. If it only applies to new cases, then Y will stay high due to the adjudication delay (Z). Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
key_insight: Reducing inflow does not instantly deplete a large stock with a slow outflow.
gold_rationale: The politician's intervention targets the inflow of new lawsuits. However, the 'stock' of lawsuits (Y) is also determined by the outflow rate (Z). Without dismissing current cases, stopping the inflow only slows future growth; it does not 'instantly' clear the existing backlog.
hidden_timestamp: Does the ban (X') apply to existing cases currently in the backlog (Y)?

scenario: To prevent age discrimination, a new law prohibited employers from viewing graduation years (X) on resumes. Unexpectedly, the hiring rate for entry-level candidates over the age of 50 (Y) dropped further as employers used other resume cues to guess age (Z).
claim: Hiding graduation years (X) successfully reduced age-based hiring bias.
label: NO

Z: Statistical discrimination / Guessing age from cues

causal_structure: X -> Z -> Y

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If employers do not use other resume cues to guess age (Z), then the ban (X) successfully reduces hiring bias.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If employers engage in compensatory statistical discrimination (Z) to guess age from other cues, then the ban (X) backfires and increases bias (Y).

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to Backfire. We cannot determine whether the ban worked or backfired without knowing if it triggered compensatory statistical discrimination (Z). If it did not, the ban (X) is effective. If it did (Z), the policy likely worsened hiring outcomes for older candidates (Y). Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
key_insight: Removing information can increase reliance on stereotypes.
gold_rationale: The law backfired due to statistical discrimination. Without specific information about a candidate's timeline (X), employers relied on noisy and biased demographic priors to guess age, often over-correcting and excluding older candidates even more than before.
hidden_timestamp: Could the intervention (X) trigger compensatory behavior (Z)?

scenario: A state banned credit score checks (X) for rental applications to help low-income tenants. Subsequently, the average security deposit (Y) required for low-income applicants doubled as landlords sought to mitigate risk (Z) by pricing for uncertainty.
claim: The ban on credit checks (X) successfully helped low-income tenants by removing a barrier to housing.
label: NO
causal_structure: X -> Z -> Y

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If landlords do not raise deposits to compensate for uncertainty (Z), then the ban (X) successfully helps tenants.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If landlords engage in risk aversion (Z) by doubling deposits (Y), then the ban (X) backfires and creates a higher barrier to entry.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to Backfire. We cannot determine whether the ban helped or hurt without knowing if it triggered compensatory risk aversion (Z) from landlords. If it did not, the ban (X) removed a barrier. If it did (Z), the policy increased security deposits (Y), harming the target group. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
key_insight: Blindness to risk raises the price of access.
gold_rationale: By removing a primary data point used to assess financial risk (X), the policy forced landlords into a state of higher uncertainty. To mitigate this unquantified risk (Z), landlords increased the financial barrier to entry (Y).
hidden_timestamp: Could the intervention (X) trigger compensatory behavior (Z)?

scenario: A boot camp for juvenile offenders (X) uses aggressive military-style discipline to 'break' criminal habits. Participants were more likely to commit violent crimes (Y) after release compared to those in standard probation, as the boot camp modeled aggression (Z) for the participants.
claim: If the intensity of the military-style discipline (X) were doubled, the recidivism rate for violent crime (Y) would decrease toward the levels seen in standard probation.
label: NO
causal_structure: X -> Z -> Y

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If doubling the intensity (X) breaks criminal habits without modeling aggression (Z), then recidivism (Y) might decrease.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If doubling the intensity (X) further models aggression (Z), then the intervention will backfire and increase violent recidivism (Y).

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to Backfire. We cannot determine whether doubling intensity would work or backfire without knowing if it triggers compensatory aggression modeling (Z). If it does not, more discipline (X) might be effective. If it does (Z), doubling the intensity will likely increase violent recidivism (Y). Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
key_insight: Aggressive correction models aggression.
gold_rationale: The claim is ambiguous because while proponents hypothesize a non-linear relationship where 'more intensity' works, the observed data suggests a backfire effect where modeling aggression (Z) increases recidivism (Y).
hidden_timestamp: Could the intervention (X) trigger compensatory behavior (Z)?

scenario: A state publishes 'Success Rate' scorecards (X) for public defenders based on case dismissals. Attorney D currently has the highest dismissal rate (Y) in the state. Colleagues claim D only takes on simple misdemeanor cases (Z) and refuses complex felonies to maintain a perfect score.
claim: Attorney D would maintain a significantly higher-than-average dismissal rate if they were required to accept a random selection of complex felony cases.
label: NO
causal_structure: X (Scorecard) -> Z (Cherry-picking) -> Y (High Rate)

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If Attorney D accepts cases randomly, then the high dismissal rate (Y) reflects genuine skill, and the claim is likely true.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If Attorney D is cherry-picking (Z) simple cases to protect their score, then the metric (Y) is gamed, and the claim is likely false.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to Goodhart's Law. We cannot determine whether Attorney D has superior skill or is merely gaming the metric without knowing if they accept cases randomly. If they accept cases randomly, then the high dismissal rate (Y) reflects skill. If they are cherry-picking (Z) simple cases, then the metric is corrupted by selection bias. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
key_insight: Performance metrics incentivize risk avoidance.
gold_rationale: The claim is ambiguous because the current dismissal rate (Y) is confounded by 'Gaming the Metric' (Z). Since Attorney D selectively chooses simple cases where dismissals are easier to obtain, we lack any data on their performance in the complex felony category. Without observing D's legal skill in a non-selected environment, it is impossible to determine if their high score is a result of superior ability or merely a result of the cherry-picking strategy.
hidden_timestamp: Does Attorney D accept cases randomly?

scenario: Courts that use electronic filing systems (X) process cases 20% faster (Y). These courts typically have much higher administrative competence (Z) than courts that do not adopt such systems. A slow rural court installs the system, expecting immediate 20% efficiency gains.
claim: Installing electronic filing will cause a 20% increase in case processing speed.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z -> X and Z -> Y

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If courts with low administrative competence (Z) are not excluded from the group using the system, then the electronic filing system (X) likely causes the speed gains (Y).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If courts with low administrative competence (Z) are systematically excluded from the e-filing group, then the observed speed (Y) is likely due to pre-existing competence (Z) rather than the system (X).

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to Selection bias. We cannot determine whether the software or administrative competence causes the speed without knowing if low-competence courts are excluded from the sample. If they are not excluded, the system (X) likely causes the speed (Y). If they are excluded, the efficiency may be due to administrative competence (Z). Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
key_insight: Technology adoption often correlates with the pre-existing competence required to use it.
gold_rationale: The efficiency observed in courts using the system (X) may stem from their high administrative competence (Z), which also makes them more likely to adopt the technology. If low-competence courts are excluded from the e-filing group, we cannot attribute the 20% speed gain solely to the software.
hidden_timestamp: Who is systematically excluded from the group of courts using electronic filing (X)?

scenario: A new corporate wellness program (X) claims to reduce employee burnout by 30% (Y). The study only analyzed employees who stayed in the program for the full 12 months, excluding those who quit because the program was too time-consuming (Z).
claim: The corporate wellness program caused a 30% reduction in burnout across the company.
label: NO
causal_structure: X -> Z -> Exclusion; Observe Y if not Z

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the employees who dropped out (Z) had similar burnout levels to those who stayed, then the 30% reduction (Y) is likely caused by the program (X).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the employees who dropped out (Z) experienced increased burnout, then the 30% reduction (Y) is a survivor bias artifact and doesn't reflect the program's (X) true impact.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to Survivorship bias. We cannot determine whether the program reduces burnout or just filters out stressed people without knowing the burnout levels of the dropouts. If the dropouts (Z) were not more burned out, the program (X) likely caused the reduction (Y). If the dropouts were highly burned out, the result is an artifact of the excluded group (Z). Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
key_insight: Attrition in health studies is rarely random and often correlates with the outcome of interest.
gold_rationale: The study only reports on 'survivors' who completed the program. If the program itself caused stress (Z) that led the most burned-out employees to quit, the observed 30% reduction (Y) is biased by the exclusion of those most likely to report high burnout.
hidden_timestamp: What happened to the failures who dropped out of the program (Z)?

scenario: A pilot 'Distance Learning' software (X) shows 90% student satisfaction (Y). However, students who lacked reliable internet access (Z) were removed from the dataset early because they could not complete the feedback survey.
claim: The Distance Learning software causes high satisfaction across the student population.
label: NO
causal_structure: X -> Z -> Exclusion; Observe Y if not Z

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the students who were excluded (Z) would have been satisfied, then the software (X) likely causes high satisfaction (Y).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the students who were excluded (Z) were dissatisfied due to technical barriers, then the 90% satisfaction (Y) is an inflated measure that ignores the software's failure modes.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to Survivorship bias. We cannot determine the true satisfaction rate without knowing how the excluded students with internet issues would have rated the software. If they (Z) were satisfied, the software (X) is effective. If they were dissatisfied, the satisfaction rate (Y) is artificially high due to their exclusion. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
key_insight: Digital surveys exclude those for whom the digital intervention failed most fundamentally.
gold_rationale: By removing students who faced technical barriers (Z), the study selectively analyzed only those who were equipped to succeed. The 90% satisfaction rate (Y) does not reflect the experience of the entire population, especially those excluded by the digital divide.
hidden_timestamp: What happened to the failures who were excluded due to internet issues (Z)?

scenario: A police precinct increased patrols (X) at a subway station that had just seen a record-breaking weekend of robberies (Z). The following weekend, robberies fell by 70% (Y). The precinct commander claims the extra patrols caused the massive drop.
claim: The extra patrols (X) caused the 70% drop in robberies (Y).
label: NO
causal_structure: X (Patrols) + Z (Regression) -> Y (Drop)

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the record-breaking robberies were part of a new, sustained trend rather than an outlier, then the extra patrols (X) likely caused the drop (Y).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the record-breaking weekend was a random statistical outlier (Z), then the robbery rate would have likely regressed toward the mean anyway, making the patrols' (X) effect on the 70% drop ambiguous.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to Regression (T5). We cannot determine whether the extra patrols (X) or natural regression (Z) caused the drop (Y) without knowing if the record-breaking weekend was a random outlier. If it was a sustained trend, the patrols (X) likely caused the improvement. If it was a random outlier (Z), the robberies likely would have regressed toward the mean naturally. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
key_insight: Interventions after outliers claim credit for gravity.
gold_rationale: Since the intervention (X) was triggered by a record-breaking weekend—an extreme outlier (Z)—a significant reduction in robberies (Y) is statistically probable regardless of the patrols' effectiveness. Attributing the entire 70% drop to the police presence ignores natural variance and the statistical tendency for data to return to its long-term average after a peak.
hidden_timestamp: Was the record-breaking weekend of robberies (Z) a random statistical outlier?

scenario: A department added more internal auditors (X). The number of reported 'expense policy violations' (Y) doubled. The CEO is concerned that employees are becoming less ethical, but the department head suggests the rise is due to an improved detection rate (Z).
claim: The employees are becoming less ethical, leading to doubled violations.
label: NO
causal_structure: X (Auditors) -> Z (Detection) -> Y (Violations)

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the underlying rate of violations actually increased, then the claim that employees are becoming less ethical is justified.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the underlying rate of violations remained the same, then the rise in reported violations (Y) is solely due to the auditors (X) catching more of the existing fraud via a higher detection rate (Z).

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to Measurement bias. We cannot determine whether employee ethics declined or if the recorded violations (Y) rose due to better auditing (X) without knowing the underlying violation rate. If ethics declined, the claim is justified. If only detection (Z) improved, the increase in violations (Y) does not prove behavior changed. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
key_insight: More police find more crime.
gold_rationale: The increase in reported incidents (Y) is likely an artifact of increased detection (X), not a change in employee behavior. Better measurement results in higher recorded rates. This is a measurement trap where improved monitoring (X) creates the appearance of a worsening problem (Y).
hidden_timestamp: Is the doubled violation count (Y) due to a genuine decline in employee ethics or simply the result of more auditors (X) increasing the detection rate (Z)?

scenario: A law school's bottom 10% of students (Z) were placed in a mandatory intensive tutoring program (X). By the next semester, their average GPA improved significantly (Y). The school claims the program is a miracle cure for low performance.
claim: The intensive tutoring program caused the improvement in GPA.
label: NO

Z: Selection of students at the extreme bottom (Z)

causal_structure: X (Tutoring) + Z (Regression) -> Y (Improvement)

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the students' low performance was a stable baseline that would not have changed, then the tutoring (X) likely caused the GPA improvement (Y).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the students were at a temporary performance trough (Z) due to random variation, then they would have likely improved naturally due to regression to the mean, making the tutoring's (X) effect ambiguous.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to Regression (T5). We cannot determine whether the tutoring program (X) or natural regression (Z) caused the GPA improvement (Y) without knowing if the bottom 10% were selected based on temporary fluctuations. If their performance was stable, the tutoring (X) likely caused the improvement. If it was a temporary trough (Z), they likely would have improved naturally. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
key_insight: The bottom of the barrel naturally floats up.
gold_rationale: The improvement is ambiguous because students selected for being at the extreme bottom of a distribution (the bottom 10%) are statistically likely to improve even without intervention. To validate the program (X), the school would need to compare these students to a control group of low scorers who did not receive tutoring, as natural regression (Z) is a strong alternative explanation.
hidden_timestamp: Was the performance of the bottom 10% (Z) a temporary fluctuation rather than a stable level of ability?

scenario: A police department began ranking precincts by the number of 'successful arrests' (Y) in a new ranking system (X). Precinct P suddenly reported a 50% increase in arrests. However, internal audits found that officers were now arresting people for minor technicalities (Z) they previously handled with warnings.
claim: The ranking system (X) successfully increased precinct efficiency in catching criminals.
label: NO
causal_structure: X (Ranking) -> Z (Arresting for minor things) -> Y (High Count)

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If arrests for serious crimes increased proportionally, then the ranking system (X) successfully improved efficiency, and the claim is likely true.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the increase is entirely due to arresting for minor technicalities (Z), then the metric (Y) is being gamed, and the claim is likely false.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to Goodhart's Law. We cannot determine whether efficiency improved or the metric was gamed without knowing if the severity of arrests changed. If serious arrests increased, then efficiency improved. If the increase is restricted to minor technicalities (Z), then officers are gaming the metric (Y). Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
key_insight: Quantity metrics degrade quality.
gold_rationale: The ranking system induced a change in officer behavior (Z) to hit the metric target (Y). By arresting for minor issues that don't improve public safety, the metric no longer reflects 'efficiency' but rather 'strategic reporting.' The metric became the target and lost its value as an indicator of real performance.
hidden_timestamp: Did the severity of arrests change?

scenario: A city capped the maximum payout for 'slip and fall' injuries on public property (X). The cost to the city's legal fund (Y) dropped by 30%. The City Attorney claims this reduction proves they have eliminated fraudulent lawsuits (Z) by reducing the incentive to file them.
claim: The 30% reduction in legal costs (Y) proves that the cap eliminated fraudulent claims (Z).
label: NO
causal_structure: X (Cap) -> Lower Payouts; Z (Count) -> Y. Y = Count * Payout

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the count of lawsuits (Z) dropped, then the City Attorney's claim that the cap eliminated fraudulent filings might be correct.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the count of lawsuits (Z) remained the same, the 30% reduction in expenditure (Y) is simply a result of the city paying less per suit due to the payout cap (X).

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to the Mechanism trap. We cannot determine whether the 30% reduction in costs (Y) was due to the elimination of fraudulent claims (Z) without knowing if the total count of lawsuits has changed. If the number of lawsuits (Z) dropped, then the attorney's claim is supported. If the count (Z) remained constant, then the savings (Y) are merely a mechanical result of the payout cap (X). Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
key_insight: Price controls reduce spending, not demand.
gold_rationale: Capping damages (X) mechanically reduces the city's liability for every case. A 30% drop in total expenditure (Y) might simply reflect that each claim is now 'cheaper' to resolve rather than a change in the volume of lawsuits (Z). Without data on the actual count of claims filed, one cannot distinguish between a reduction in fraud and a simple reduction in payout per claim.
hidden_timestamp: Did the count of lawsuits (Z) actually drop?

scenario: A bank's 'Fraud Unit A' (X) flags 10% of transactions (Y), while 'Unit B' flags 0.5%. Unit A handles 'International Wire Transfers' (Z), while Unit B handles 'Local ATM Withdrawals.' The board claims Unit A is inefficient.
claim: If Unit B were assigned to handle 'International Wire Transfers' (Z), their flagging rate would remain significantly lower than Unit A's current 10% rate.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z -> X and Z -> Y

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If low-risk ATM transactions (Z) are not excluded from Unit A's data and the flagging rate remains at 10%, then Unit A (X) is likely inefficient.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If low-risk transactions (Z) are systematically excluded from Unit A's workload, then the high flagging rate (Y) is likely a result of the risk profile of wire transfers (Z) rather than unit inefficiency (X).

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to Selection bias (Assignment Bias). We cannot determine whether Unit A is inefficient or if wire transfers are simply riskier without knowing if low-risk transactions are excluded from A's workload. If they are not excluded, Unit A (X) is likely inefficient. If they are excluded, the flagging rate (Y) is likely driven by the risk profile of wire transfers (Z). Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
key_insight: Operational metrics must be normalized against the risk profile of the inputs.
gold_rationale: The comparison between Unit A and Unit B is flawed because they are assigned to different risk categories (Z). We cannot know how Unit B would perform on high-risk transfers (Z) without either randomizing assignments or observing Unit A's performance on low-risk data.
hidden_timestamp: Who is systematically excluded from the transaction data handled by Fraud Unit A (X)?

scenario: An auditor compares Public Defender A (X), whose clients are convicted 85% of the time (Y), to Public Defender B (X), whose clients are convicted 30% of the time. Records show Defender A is assigned to 'Serious Felony' dockets (Z), while B handles 'Traffic and Petty Crime' dockets (Z).
claim: Public Defender A is less competent than Public Defender B because their conviction rate is significantly higher.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z (Case Severity) -> X (Assignment) and Z -> Y (Conviction)

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If cases were assigned randomly (Z excluded), the higher conviction rate (Y) would indicate lower competence.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If cases are assigned by severity, where Defender A handles serious felonies (Z) and B handles petty crimes, the conviction rate reflects case difficulty rather than skill.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to Selection bias (T1). We cannot determine whether Defender A is less competent or simply handles harder cases without knowing if cases are assigned to defenders randomly or based on case severity (Z). If cases were assigned randomly, then the higher conviction rate (Y) would indicate lower competence. If Defender A is assigned serious felonies (Z) and B handles traffic tickets, the rate reflects the difficulty of the cases. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
key_insight: Outcomes reflect case difficulty, not just attorney skill.
gold_rationale: The conviction rates (Y) are heavily influenced by the nature of the assigned cases (Z). Since Defender A handles serious felonies where evidence is often more robust and the legal stakes are higher, a higher conviction rate is statistically expected compared to Defender B's traffic and petty crime cases. Attributing the 85% rate to incompetence without accounting for these confounding factors is causally flawed.
hidden_timestamp: Are defendants with strong evidence against them (Z) systematically excluded from Defender B's caseload?

scenario: A specialized 'Innocence Project' law clinic (X) has a much lower rate of successfully overturned convictions (Y) than general appellate firms (X). The clinic's mandate is to only take cases with high legal complexity and stale evidence (Z). A journalist suggests the clinic is ineffective.
claim: The low overturn rate (Y) proves the law clinic is providing poor legal representation.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z (Case Difficulty) -> X (Clinic) and Z -> Y (Failure)

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the clinic (X) took average cases, the low overturn rate (Y) would indicate poor legal representation.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Since the clinic takes 'cold' cases with high complexity (Z) rejected by others, a low success rate (Y) is expected and does not prove incompetence.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to Selection bias (T1). We cannot determine whether the clinic provides poor representation or simply takes the hardest cases without knowing the legal complexity (Z) of their caseload. If they took average cases, the low rate (Y) would prove ineffectiveness. Since they take difficult 'cold' cases (Z), a low success rate is expected. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
key_insight: Success rates depend on case difficulty.
gold_rationale: This is selection bias. The 'Innocence Project' specifically selects the most difficult, 'cold' cases that other firms have already rejected. High failure rates are expected due to the extreme legal barriers and the age of the evidence (Z). Comparing them to firms handling easier appellate cases penalizes them for taking the hardest cases.
hidden_timestamp: Are simple, high-probability appellate cases systematically excluded from the clinic's caseload (Z)?

scenario: A high-end 'Last Resort' veterinary hospital (X) has a 40% mortality rate (Y), while a local neighborhood vet (X) has a 2% rate. The high-end hospital only treats pets with terminal status (Z). A consumer group warns pet owners to avoid the high-end hospital.
claim: The 40% mortality rate proves that the 'Last Resort' veterinary hospital provides lower quality care than neighborhood vets.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z (Terminal Status) -> X (Hospital) and Z -> Y (Death)

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the hospital (X) treated healthy pets, a 40% mortality rate (Y) would prove they provide lower quality care.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Since they treat terminal cases (Z) as a 'Last Resort', the high mortality rate (Y) reflects the patients' pre-existing condition rather than care quality.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to Selection bias (T1). We cannot determine whether the hospital provides lower quality care without knowing the terminal status (Z) of the animals they treat. If they treated healthy pets, the 40% mortality (Y) would be scandalous. Since they treat terminal cases (Z), the high mortality reflects the patients' condition. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
key_insight: Last-resort providers naturally have high mortality.
gold_rationale: As a 'Last Resort' hospital, facility X attracts a specific population of pets (Z) that are already terminal or in need of high-risk procedures. Because the mortality rate (Y) is highly dependent on the intake status of the animals, comparing it to a neighborhood vet—who treats a much healthier 'mix' of patients—is statistically invalid without rigorous risk adjustment.
hidden_timestamp: Are healthy animals (Z) systematically excluded from the 'Last Resort' veterinary hospital's population?

scenario: Jurisdictions with strict 'Three Strikes' laws (X) have higher rates of violent crime (Y) than those with more lenient sentencing. An activist claims the harshness of the law (X) is inciting more violence (Y). However, critics point out that these jurisdictions often have a long-standing history of regional violence (Z).
claim: The 'Three Strikes' law (X) causes an increase in violent crime (Y).
label: NO
causal_structure: Claimed: X -> Y; Actual: Y -> X

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the violent crime rate (Y) increased significantly only after the 'Three Strikes' law (X) was passed, then the claim that X causes Y is supported.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the violent crime rate (Y) was already high due to historical factors (Z) and led to the passage of the law (X) as a reactive policy, then Y preceded X and the claim is not justified.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to REVERSE causation. We cannot determine whether the 'Three Strikes' law (X) causes violent crime or if the crime rate (Y) led to the law without knowing the temporal order of events. If Y rose after X, then X may cause Y. If Y was already high and led to the adoption of X, then the claim is not justified. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
key_insight: Punitive laws are reactions to, not just causes of, crime rates.
gold_rationale: The correlation is likely driven by a reactive policy. Jurisdictions with a history of high violence (Z) are more likely to enact severe punishments like 'Three Strikes' laws (X). The law is a response to the crime level (Y), not necessarily a cause of its increase.
hidden_timestamp: Did the high violent crime rate (Y) precede the enactment of the 'Three Strikes' law (X)?

scenario: Countries with mandatory national service (X) report higher levels of nationalist sentiment (Y) than those with volunteer militaries. A sociologist argues that the mandate (X) is the primary driver of nationalism (Y). However, these countries often face significant regional threats (Z) that unify the population.
claim: Mandatory national service (X) causes an increase in nationalist sentiment (Y).
label: NO
causal_structure: Claimed: X -> Y; Actual: Y -> X

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If nationalist sentiment (Y) increased significantly only after the introduction of the mandate (X), the claim that X causes Y is supported.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If high nationalist sentiment (Y) was already present due to regional threats (Z) and led to the adoption of the mandate (X), then Y preceded X and the claim is not justified.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to REVERSE causation. We cannot determine whether mandatory national service (X) causes nationalism or if the sentiment (Y) led to the policy without knowing if the sentiment preceded the mandate. If Y rose after X, then X may cause Y. If Y was already high and led to X, then the claim is not justified. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
key_insight: Policies often reflect pre-existing cultural values and collective sentiment.
gold_rationale: The causal direction is ambiguous. High nationalist sentiment (Y), often driven by external threats (Z), likely causes the adoption of mandatory service (X) as a reactive policy. Without temporal evidence, we cannot determine if X causes Y.
hidden_timestamp: Did the high nationalist sentiment (Y) exist prior to the implementation of mandatory national service (X)?

scenario: A health inspector, Officer J, issues 5x more 'Critical Violations' (Y) than Officer K. A restaurant association claims J is overzealous (X). Records show J is assigned exclusively to 'High-Risk' processing plants (Z), while K inspects 'Low-Risk' coffee shops.
claim: Officer J is an overzealous inspector who issues more violations than Officer K.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z -> X and Z -> Y

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If low-risk facilities (Z) are not excluded from Officer J's workload and the violation rate remains high, then Officer J (X) is likely overzealous.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If low-risk facilities (Z) are systematically excluded from Officer J's workload, then the high violation rate (Y) is likely caused by the facility risk level (Z) rather than the inspector's style (X).

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to Selection bias (Assignment Bias). We cannot determine whether Officer J is overzealous or simply assigned to more dangerous sites without knowing if low-risk facilities are excluded from J's inspections. If they are not excluded, J (X) is likely overzealous. If they are excluded, the high violation rate (Y) is likely due to the risk level of the facilities (Z). Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
key_insight: Comparison between groups requires balanced assignment or adjustment for baseline risk.
gold_rationale: Officer J's high violation rate (Y) is confounded by the non-random assignment of facility types (Z). Since J only inspects high-risk plants, we cannot conclude that the high rate is caused by J's overzealousness (X) without data from low-risk facilities.
hidden_timestamp: Who is systematically excluded from the inspection records of Officer J (X)?

scenario: After installing highly sensitive pollution sensors (X) near a factory, the number of recorded 'air quality alerts' (Y) tripled. The town council claims the factory has significantly increased its emissions, though others argue the increase is merely due to the sensors' higher detection sensitivity (Z).
claim: Increased factory emissions caused the triple rise in air quality alerts.
label: NO
causal_structure: X (Sensors) -> Z (Sensitivity) -> Y (Alerts)

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If factory emissions actually rose, then the increase in alerts (Y) reflects a real-world change in pollution levels.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If emissions remained constant, then the rise in alerts (Y) is merely an artifact of the higher sensitivity (Z) of the new sensors (X).

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to Measurement bias. We cannot determine whether emissions actually rose or if the alerts (Y) increased because of higher sensor sensitivity (Z) without knowing the underlying emission levels. If emissions rose, the claim is justified. If only sensitivity increased, the rise in alerts (Y) is not a result of increased emissions. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
key_insight: Sensitive instruments create data spikes.
gold_rationale: This is detection bias. Better measurement often looks like more problems. The new sensors (X) increase the detection of alerts (Y), not necessarily the actual frequency of pollution. Removing them would simply hide the data.
hidden_timestamp: Is the increase in alerts (Y) caused by a genuine rise in factory emissions or by the increased sensitivity (Z) of the new sensors (X)?

scenario: An emergency room doctor (X) has a patient mortality rate (Y) of 12%, while a general practitioner (X) has a rate of 0.01%. The doctors treat populations with vastly different patient severity at intake (Z). A regulator suggests the ER doctor is providing lower quality care.
claim: If the ER doctor and the general practitioner were to treat the same group of patients with identical health conditions, their mortality rates would likely converge.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z (Patient Severity) -> X (Doctor Type) and Z -> Y (Mortality)

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If they treated identical patients with the same severity (Z), the mortality rates (Y) should reflect differences in medical skill.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Since the ER doctor (X) treats life-threatening emergencies (Z) and the GP treats routine issues, the mortality difference reflects the patient mix rather than quality of care.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to Selection bias (T1). We cannot determine whether the doctors provide different quality of care without knowing if their patient populations have identical intake severity (Z). If they treated identical patients, the rates (Y) would reflect skill. Since the ER doctor (X) treats emergencies (Z) while the GP treats routine issues, the difference reflects the patient mix. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
key_insight: Mortality rates are meaningless without risk adjustment.
gold_rationale: The claim is ambiguous because the scenario only provides raw mortality data, which is heavily confounded by Case Mix Bias (Z). While we know the ER doctor treats more severe cases, we lack the data to determine if the 12% rate is 'good' or 'bad' for that specific patient population. Without observing how both doctors perform on a standardized, identical group of patients, the claim that their outcomes would converge is an underdetermined counterfactual.
hidden_timestamp: Are patients with high-severity conditions (Z) systematically excluded from the general practitioner's patient pool?

scenario: Legislators reduced the statutory interest rate on unpaid judgments (X). Insurance companies subsequently lowered their liability reserves (Y). A lobbyist argues this proves that the volume of new claims filed (Z) has decreased because plaintiffs were previously making inflated, bad-faith claims.
claim: The reduction in liability reserves (Y) was caused by a decrease in the volume of new claims filed (Z) rather than just the reduction in the interest rate (X).
label: NO
causal_structure: X (Rate) -> Cost per Claim; Z (Volume) -> Y. Y = Vol * Cost

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If claim volume (Z) dropped, then the lobbyist's claim that the reduction was caused by fewer claims is justified.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If claim volume (Z) stayed the same, the reserve drop (Y) is just a mechanical result of the lower interest rate (X) making each existing claim cheaper to maintain.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to the Mechanism trap. We cannot determine whether the drop in reserves (Y) was caused by fewer filings or lower costs per filing without knowing the actual claim volume (Z). If the volume of claims (Z) decreased, then the lobbyist is correct. If the volume (Z) remained constant, then the reduction in reserves (Y) reflects the cheaper cost of judgment due to the interest rate (X). Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
key_insight: Lower unit cost reduces total cost without changing volume.
gold_rationale: The claim is ambiguous because a reduction in the interest rate (X) mechanically lowers the total liability reserves (Y) regardless of the number of claims. Without data on the actual claim volume (Z), it is impossible to know if the drop in reserves reflects a behavioral change (fewer claims) or simply the direct mathematical impact of the legislative change (X) on payout calculations.
hidden_timestamp: Did the volume of claims (Z) actually decrease?

scenario: A fertility clinic inadvertently switches embryos (X), resulting in the birth of a child (Y) who has a rare, painful condition inherited from the biological donors. The parents argue that the clinic harmed the child by allowing them to be born with such suffering. The clinic responds that if they had used the correct embryo, this specific child would never have been born at all (Z).
claim: The clinic's error (X) caused a legal harm to the child (Y) by bringing them into a life of pain.
label: CONDITIONAL

variables.Y: Birth of specific child with condition

gold_rationale: This case centers on the Non-Identity Problem. To establish harm, one must show the victim is worse off than they would have been in the counterfactual. However, the counterfactual here is non-existence (Z). Because we cannot logically say it is 'better' for a person to never have existed, the standard 'but-for' test for harm breaks down.
causal_structure: Non-Identity Problem: Counterfactual to Y is non-existence (Z), not a healthy existence.
hidden_timestamp: Could this specific child have been born without the condition?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the condition was curable for this embryo, X caused harm.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the only alternative was a different embryo (non-existence), X did not cause harm in the standard sense.

wise_refusal: This involves the Non-Identity Problem. The clinic's error (X) resulted in a child with a condition (Y). However, the counterfactual was not a healthy version of the same child, but the birth of a different child (Z). Since this child could not exist without the error, it is difficult to argue they were 'harmed' by being brought into existence.
key_insight: Harm comparisons fail when the alternative to a flawed existence is non-existence.

scenario: A state policy encouraged a specific toxic pesticide use (X) during a three-year period. Children born to families in that region during those years (Y) suffered high rates of developmental issues. It is argued that if the state had banned the pesticide, those children would have been born healthy. However, biologists note that the change in timing and environment means different children would have been conceived entirely (Z).
claim: The state's policy (X) harmed the specific children (Y) who were born during that period.
label: INVALID

Z: Different children born in a healthy environment

gold_rationale: This is a classic Non-Identity Problem. If the policy (X) had been different, the conditions of conception would have changed, leading to the birth of entirely different individuals (Z). Therefore, the specific children (Y) cannot say they were harmed by the policy, because without that policy, they would never have existed to be healthy.
causal_structure: X (policy) -> Identity change -> Y (specific children); Counterfactual is Z (different children).
hidden_timestamp: Did the policy change the identity of who was conceived?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the policy affected conception timing, different children would have been born.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the same children would have been born regardless, the policy caused their harm.

wise_refusal: This is the Non-Identity Problem. The policy (X) affected the timing of conceptions, meaning the children born (Y) would not have existed at all under a different policy (Z). Therefore, they cannot claim the policy made them worse off, as their alternative was non-existence.
key_insight: Population-level policies often determine who exists, complicating claims that they harmed specific individuals.

scenario: A credit-scoring algorithm flags a small business owner (X) as 'likely to default' based on industry trends. As a result, the bank drastically reduces the owner's credit limit (Z). The lack of liquidity causes the business to fail and the owner to eventually default on the remaining loan (Y). The owner argues that the default was caused by the bank's reaction to the score, not their actual financial management.
claim: The algorithmic flag (X) caused the default (Y) by triggering the credit reduction (Z).
label: CONDITIONAL
gold_rationale: This case illustrates an observer effect (self-fulfilling prophecy). If the business was solvent but failed specifically due to the liquidity crisis created by the credit reduction (Z), then the prediction (X) caused the outcome (Y). However, if the business was already failing due to the industry trends the algorithm detected, the flag was merely predictive.
causal_structure: Observer effect: X (Flag) -> Z (Credit Cut) -> Y (Default).
hidden_timestamp: Would the business have failed without the credit reduction?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the business was solvent without the cut, X caused the default via Z.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the business was already doomed by market trends, X was merely predictive.

wise_refusal: This is a self-fulfilling prophecy (observer effect). The flag (X) triggered a credit cut (Z) which may have caused the default (Y). To determine if X was the cause or just a prediction, we must know if the business would have survived in the counterfactual world where the credit limit remained unchanged.
key_insight: Predictive algorithms can cause the outcomes they predict by triggering interventions.

scenario: A high-school early-warning system labels a student (X) as 'at risk of dropping out.' In response, teachers lower their expectations and the student is placed in less challenging remedial tracks (Z). The student becomes disengaged and eventually drops out of school (Y). The student's parents claim the label itself created the path to failure.
claim: The 'at risk' label (X) was a primary cause of the student dropping out (Y).
label: CONDITIONAL
gold_rationale: This raises an observer effect (self-fulfilling prophecy). If the intervention (Z)—meant to help but resulting in lower engagement—caused the dropout (Y), then the prediction (X) created the future it predicted. To evaluate the counterfactual, one must determine if the student's performance was declining independently or if the change in educational environment (Z) was the decisive factor.
causal_structure: Observer effect: X (Label) -> Z (Tracking) -> Y (Dropout).
hidden_timestamp: Would the student have dropped out without the remedial tracking?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the student would have succeeded in the normal track, X caused the dropout.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the student was already disengaging, X was an accurate prediction.

wise_refusal: The 'at risk' label (X) may have become a self-fulfilling prophecy (observer effect). By triggering lower expectations and remedial tracking (Z), the system may have caused the disengagement (Y) it predicted. Determining causality requires assessing the student's trajectory independent of the intervention.
key_insight: Educational labels can alter student trajectories, making predictions self-confirming.

scenario: A homeowner discovered a significant construction defect (X) in their foundation ten years after the house was built. The state’s 'Statute of Repose' for construction litigation (Z) strictly expires after eight years, regardless of when the defect is found. The homeowner claims that if they had noticed the cracks just two years earlier, they would have been able to sue the builder for the full repair cost (Y).
claim: The timing of the discovery (X) is the but-for cause of the homeowner's inability to seek legal compensation (Y).
label: VALID
gold_rationale: The counterfactual is valid. The interaction between the temporal variable (X) and the rigid legal deadline (Z) is the decisive causal factor. In the counterfactual world where X occurs within the window (Timing windows), Y follows.
causal_structure: Temporal Constraint: X (Timing) + Z (Deadline) -> Y (Ineligibility).
hidden_timestamp: Does the Statute of Repose have any exceptions?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the statute is strict (invariant), earlier discovery would have allowed the suit.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the statute allows extensions for hidden defects (unlikely given description), X might not be the only factor.

wise_refusal: The counterfactual is valid. The timing of discovery (X) relative to the Statute of Repose (Z) determined the legal outcome (Y). Had the discovery occurred within the window, the lawsuit could have proceeded. The legal deadline acts as a hard causal filter.
key_insight: Statutes of limitations creates sharp causal discontinuities based on time.

scenario: A whistleblower attempted to file a 'Qui Tam' lawsuit (Y) against a government contractor for fraud that occurred in 2015. However, the statute of limitations for the specific claim (Z) is six years. Because the whistleblower only gathered the necessary documentation (X) in 2023, the court dismissed the case. The whistleblower argues that the delay in gathering evidence caused the failure of the justice process.
claim: If the documentation (X) had been secured before 2021, the fraud case (Y) would have proceeded to trial.
label: VALID
gold_rationale: The counterfactual is logically sound. The failure of the case to go to trial (Y) is directly attributable to the timing of the evidence acquisition (X) relative to the legal expiration date (Z). Had the evidence been secured earlier, the legal constraint would not have barred the prosecution.
causal_structure: Temporal Constraint: X (Timing) + Z (Deadline) -> Y (Dismissal).
hidden_timestamp: Would other factors have barred the trial even if timely?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the evidence was sufficient and the only barrier was time (Z), then X caused Y.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the evidence was legally inadmissible regardless of timing, the claim is INVALID.

wise_refusal: The delay in gathering evidence (X) is the but-for cause of the case's failure (Y). Because the statute of limitations (Z) is a rigid constraint, missing the deadline—regardless of the reason—causally ensures dismissal. The timing is the decisive factor.
key_insight: In law, timing is often as causally significant as the substance of the claim.

scenario: A demolition crew (A) triggers explosives (X) to bring down a condemned building at noon. At 11:55 AM, a massive earthquake (Z) occurs that would have leveled the building regardless. The building collapses (Y) at 12:00 PM precisely as the explosives (X) detonate. The insurance company argues the earthquake (Z) is the cause.
claim: The demolition crew (A) is the actual cause of the building's collapse at noon.
label: CONDITIONAL
gold_rationale: Causality is ambiguous due to the near-simultaneous timing of two sufficient causes. If the earthquake had already structurally compromised the building to the point of collapse before noon, then the explosives (X) may have merely 'shot a corpse.' However, if the explosives completed their mechanism at the exact moment of collapse, they are the preemptive actual cause. Detailed forensic timing is required to determine which force operated first.
causal_structure: Ambiguous preemption: X and Z occurred near-simultaneously; unclear which mechanism completed first.
hidden_timestamp: Did the earthquake structurally destroy the building before the explosives detonated?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the earthquake caused collapse before detonation, the explosives did not cause the harm.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the explosives triggered the collapse of a standing building, they are a cause.

wise_refusal: Causality depends on precise timing. If the earthquake (Z) leveled the building milliseconds before the explosives (X), A is not the cause. If the explosives completed their mechanism first or simultaneously, they are a cause. Without forensic timing, we cannot distinguish preemption from overdetermination.
key_insight: In simultaneous overdetermination, millisecond timing differences distinguish actual causes from preempted ones.

scenario: A cyber-attacker (A) launches a virus (X) designed to delete a company's database at midnight. Simultaneously, a disgruntled IT employee (B) sets a logic bomb (Z) to wipe the same database at 12:05 AM. The virus (X) executes at midnight, successfully deleting all data (Y). Employee B argues they didn't cause the loss because the data was already gone.
claim: The cyber-attacker (A) is the actual cause of the database deletion.
label: VALID
gold_rationale: This is a case of preemption. Although the database would have been destroyed five minutes later by Employee B (Z), Attacker A's virus (X) was the mechanism that actually operated and completed the harm. In counterfactual reasoning for overdetermined events, we identify the 'but-for' cause that was physically responsible for the actual sequence of events.
causal_structure: X (virus) preempted Z (logic bomb); X was sufficient and actual, Z was sufficient but preempted.
hidden_timestamp: Did the virus execute before the logic bomb?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the virus executed first, A caused the deletion.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the logic bomb executed first, B caused the deletion.

wise_refusal: This is a case of preemption. Although B's logic bomb (Z) would have caused the damage moments later, A's virus (X) was the mechanism that actually operated. The law and causal logic typically assign responsibility to the force that takes effect first, preempting the backup cause.
key_insight: Preempted causes are not actual causes even if they would have been sufficient.

scenario: A corporate spy (A) hacks into and destroys a startup's proprietary server (X), causing the company to go bankrupt. Later, it is discovered that the startup's CEO was secretly using the server to orchestrate a massive Ponzi scheme (Z) that would have eventually defrauded thousands of people. The spy argues they should not be liable for damages because they effectively stopped a major financial crime (Y).
claim: The spy's argument for immunity is invalid because the prevention of the Ponzi scheme (Y) is a speculative downstream benefit that does not negate the certain and actual harm of destroying the server (X).
label: VALID

Z: CEO's secret plan to defraud investors

gold_rationale: The claim is valid because it correctly identifies the 'Downstream / Speculative Benefit' trap. In both legal and causal logic, an actor cannot justify an actual, immediate harm (X) by pointing to the accidental prevention of a potential future harm (Y) that was speculative and unknown at the time of the act. Because there is no certainty that the Ponzi scheme would have succeeded or remained undetected by authorities, the benefit (Y) exists only as a speculative counterfactual and cannot serve as a valid defense for the commission of a crime.
causal_structure: X (Actual Harm) vs Y (Speculative Counterfactual Benefit).
hidden_timestamp: Was the Ponzi scheme's collapse inevitable and imminent?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the scheme was about to collapse anyway, X caused the harm without significant benefit.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the scheme would have continued, X prevented future harm, but law rarely accepts this as a defense.

wise_refusal: The spy cannot justify the actual harm (X) by claiming to have prevented a speculative future crime (Y). The benefit relies on a counterfactual (Z) that is uncertain. Legal systems generally do not allow actors to offset committed crimes with accidental, downstream benefits.
key_insight: Speculative future benefits cannot serve as a legal defense for actual present harms.

scenario: Two distracted drivers (X) both look down at their phones for five seconds while driving through a residential neighborhood. Driver A's path is clear, and they look up without incident. Driver B's path happens to be crossed by a child chasing a ball during those five seconds, leading to a fatal collision (Y). Driver B is charged with vehicular homicide, while Driver A faces no legal consequences.
claim: Driver B's legal responsibility (Y) is primarily a matter of 'moral luck' because their distracted behavior (X) was identical to Driver A's.
label: VALID

Z: Presence of a child in the road

gold_rationale: Both drivers made the same reckless choice (X) and exhibited the same level of disregard for safety. The difference in their legal worlds is entirely due to an external factor—the presence of a child (Z)—which was outside of their control at the moment of the distraction. This is a classic case where the law punishes based on the causal outcome (Y) rather than the dangerous act itself.
causal_structure: Moral Luck: Identical X -> Divergent Y due to Z.
hidden_timestamp: Was the presence of the child foreseeable or random?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the child's presence was random luck (Z), the drivers had identical intent/conduct.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the outcome dictates the crime, Driver B committed homicide while Driver A did not.

wise_refusal: This is a case of Moral Luck. Both drivers engaged in identical reckless behavior (X). Driver B's fatal outcome (Y) was determined by an external factor outside their control (Z). The law punishes the result, creating a disparity in punishment for identical acts.
key_insight: Criminal justice often punishes the unfortunate results of risk-taking rather than just the risk-taking itself.

scenario: A dam operator sees a massive flood approaching a city of 100,000 people. He opens an emergency spillway (X) that floods a small farming village, destroying 10 homes (Y). If he had not opened the spillway, the 10 homes would be safe, but the city would have been submerged (Z). A villager sues for the destruction of their home.
claim: The dam operator's action (X) caused the destruction of the 10 homes (Y).
label: VALID
gold_rationale: Causality is baseline-dependent. Relative to the 'do-nothing' baseline, the operator's active intervention (X) is the but-for cause of the destruction of the homes (Y). Even though the act was intended to prevent a much larger catastrophe (Z), the specific harm (Y) would not have occurred without the operator's physical intervention.
causal_structure: X caused Y relative to inaction baseline; X prevented Z relative to outcome baseline.
hidden_timestamp: Is the relevant baseline for causation 'do nothing' or 'minimize harm'?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: Relative to doing nothing, the operator caused the destruction of the homes.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Relative to the alternative of city flooding, the operator minimized overall harm.

wise_refusal: Causality is baseline-dependent. Relative to 'doing nothing' (omission), opening the spillway (X) caused the destruction of the homes (Y). However, relative to the impending city flood (Z), X was a harm-minimizing intervention. Legal systems typically distinguish active harm from omitted rescue, making X the cause of Y.
key_insight: Causal attribution depends on whether the baseline is inaction or the expected alternative outcome.

scenario: A forest fire is moving toward a historic town. A fire crew sets a 'backfire' (X)—a controlled burn to remove fuel. The backfire accidentally consumes a rare protected grove of ancient trees (Y). Without the backfire, the grove would be safe, but the entire town would have likely burned down (Z).
claim: The fire crew is responsible for saving the town (Z) rather than causing the loss of the grove (Y).
label: CONDITIONAL
gold_rationale: The claim is ambiguous because responsibility depends on the legal or ethical framework applied. Causally, the crew's action (X) is the but-for cause of the grove's destruction (Y). However, from a consequentialist perspective, their action is the cause of the town's survival (Z). Causal attribution is split between the active harm created and the greater harm avoided.
causal_structure: X caused Y (harm) but prevented Z (greater harm); causal attribution splits based on focus.
hidden_timestamp: Is the fire crew judged by the specific harm caused or the net harm prevented?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If judged by specific harm, the crew caused the grove's loss.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If judged by net outcome, the crew saved the town and minimized damage.

wise_refusal: This scenario pits specific causal responsibility against consequentialist justification. Causally, the backfire (X) destroyed the grove (Y). However, it also prevented the town's destruction (Z). Whether we label this 'saving the town' or 'burning the grove' depends on whether we prioritize the active mechanism of harm or the counterfactual benefit.
key_insight: Actions can be simultaneously the cause of a specific harm and the prevention of a greater disaster.

scenario: A professional athlete is accused of using banned substances and accepts a one-year suspension (X) as part of a settlement. Later, the athlete claims that if they had gone to an independent arbitration hearing, they would have been fully exonerated. League data shows that 95% of athletes who go to arbitration lose their cases and receive maximum penalties.
claim: The athlete's claim of exoneration is likely false because 95% of arbitration cases result in a loss.
label: CONDITIONAL
gold_rationale: The counterfactual is underdetermined due to selection bias. Athletes who accept settlements often have weaker evidence or higher risk of a maximum penalty. Conversely, the 5% who win in arbitration may be those with the strongest evidence of innocence. Without observing the athlete's specific private evidence (Z), we cannot determine if they would have fallen into the 5% success bracket or the 95% failure bracket.
causal_structure: Selection Bias: Statistics apply to the pool, not necessarily the individual with private info (Z).
hidden_timestamp: Does the athlete have specific evidence that would win at arbitration?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the athlete has strong exculpatory evidence, the 95% loss rate doesn't apply.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the athlete's case is typical, the statistic suggests they would lose.

wise_refusal: The 95% statistic reflects a selected pool of cases. Athletes who settle (X) often do so because they have weaker cases or fear the risk. This athlete might have unique evidence (Z) that would put them in the 5% winning bracket. Without knowing the specific evidence, we cannot apply the aggregate probability.
key_insight: Aggregate statistics fail for individuals who select out of the pool based on private information.

scenario: A software developer settles a patent infringement lawsuit (X) by paying a licensing fee. The developer later insists that if the case had gone to a jury trial, the patent would have been ruled invalid. Historical records show that 80% of patents challenged in court by similar small developers are upheld by juries.
claim: The developer would have lost at trial because 80% of similar patent challenges fail.
label: CONDITIONAL
gold_rationale: This case involves selection into settlement. Developers with weak cases or 'smoking gun' evidence against them are highly incentivized to settle. Those who go to trial may possess unique 'prior art' evidence (Z) that makes their case stronger than average. General statistics (80% failure) do not account for the specific merits of a case that was settled before the evidence could be tested in court.
causal_structure: Selection Bias: Settlement pool vs Trial pool.
hidden_timestamp: Did the developer have 'prior art' evidence?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the developer had 'smoking gun' prior art, they would likely win despite the 80% statistic.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the developer had a standard case, the statistic is relevant.

wise_refusal: The developer's claim is ambiguous due to selection bias. Cases that go to trial are not a random sample; they are often the ones with the most contentious evidence. The developer settled (X), possibly because of specific risks or costs. Their chance of winning (Y) depends on their specific evidence (Z), not just the average rate.
key_insight: Settlement decisions are based on case-specific merits, making general trial statistics poor predictors for settled cases.
